causal_sentence: in an attempt to reduce the ostracism experience to a level that would no longer be aversive, we (in study 1) convinced participants that they were playing cyberball against a computer, yet still found comparable negative impact compared to when the participants thought they were being ostracized by real others.

studies have shown that people subjected to ostracism for a short period of time report worsened mood, anger, and lower levels of four state measures of needs proposed by williams (1997, 2001) to be threatened by ostracism: belonging, control, self-esteem, and meaningful existence.

recently, williams, cheung, and choi (2000) reported that individuals who played a virtual ball-toss game on the computer, ostensibly with others who were logged on to the website, also reported worsened mood and lower need levels.
additionally, if given the opportunity to make spatial judgments with a new group of individuals, ostracized participants were more likely to conform to this groups unanimously incorrect answers.

if the identity of the source is an important component in determining the aversiveness of ostracism, then targets who are ostracized by two human players should report lower levels of primary needs than targets who are ostracized by two computer generated players or targets who are included in the game.
they were told that performance in the game was unimportant, and instead, the game was merely a means for them to engage their mental visualization skills.
if assigned to the ostracism condition, participants received the ball twice at the beginning of the game, and for the remaining time, never received the ball again.
degrees of freedom vary slightly in the analyses here and in study 2 because of occasional missing data.
discussion in study 1, we found that compared to included participants, ostracized participants reported lower levels on the state measures of the four needs.
moreover, ostracized participants also reported feeling angrier and enjoyed the game less than included participants.

that is, while some have reported worsened mood following ostracism (williams, 2001) or rejection (leary, koch, & hechenbleiker, 2001), others have failed to see an effect on mood following social exclusion (twenge, baumeister, tice, & stucke, 2001; twenge, catanese, & baumeister, 2002).

although the ostracism manipulation adversely affected participants in accordance with previous ostracism research, whether participants were ostracized by humans or the computer had no effect on their self-reported need levels, or enjoyment of the game.

oddly enough, the only impact that the human/computer manipulation had was the unexpected interaction showing that being ostracized by a computer made participants angrier than being ostracized by humans.

based on comments made during the interviews it would seem that this result was due to a violation of the basic assumption that the computer is a tool to serve humans and hence should not deliberately act to distress or alienate them.

journal of experimental social psychology 40 (2004) 560-567 563 system that is quick to perceive social exclusion and feel the associated pain, so that the individual is motivated to make changes that will eliminate the ostracism.
although we assessed their perceptions in a post experimental interview, it is possible that experimenter bias may have influenced our perceptions of their answers.

thus, although we think this is rather implausible, it is possible that participants simply did not attend to our instruction about who they were playing the ball game with, and that is why we found no main effects or interactions with the human/computer manipulation on the self-reported needs.

that we found one interaction on the measure of anger (in an unexpected direction, we might add), argues against this criticism that participants were not attentive to the human/computer manipulation; however, it is possible that this interaction was spurious.
it may well be that to feel threats to the four needs an individual must attribute some sort of sinister intent on the part of the sources (kramer, 1994).

if the needs that are threatened by ostracism require some higher level interpretation of the ostracism event, then we would expect this manipulation to eliminate the negative impact when participants viewed the ostracism behavior of the sources as outside their control.
if, however, the fundamental needs are affected without cognitive intervention, then manipulations aimed at reducing sinister attributions may have no impact at all.

if ostracized individuals know that the reason they are not being thrown the ball has nothing to do with them personally, but rather the other participants (be they human or computer) are simply following a script, will they still report reduced levels of the four needs?
if so, we believe this suggests that it is the perception of ones own ostracism, not ones understanding of it, that is immediately threatening.
because there was no computer malfunction that could easily account for these incorrect reports, all participants were retained in the analyses.

specifically, participants who were ostracized reported feeling angrier, more hurt, and that they enjoyed the game less than participants who were included in the game, (smallest f was for anger, f ð1; 69þ ¼ 8:3, p ¼ :005).
participants who played the computer, however, reported more hurt feelings simply when they were ostracized, regardless of whether or not the computer game had been scripted.
discussion the results of study 2 largely replicated the findings of study 1. once again, we found that ostracism resulted in lower self-reported levels of four needs.
however, in study 2 we also found that ostracism resulted in less positive mood than did inclusion.
we regard this inconsistency as evidence of the less than robust effect of social exclusion on mood.
have also demonstrated, regardless of whether mood is affected by social exclusion, it does not mediate need levels nor subsequent behaviors.

more importantly for the present investigation, ostracism by computers was just as unpleasant as ostracism by humans, and furthermore, it did not matter whether the human or computer players were perceived to have a choice as to whom they threw the ball.
thus, once again, it appears that ostracism, per se, is felt immediately as a negative and depleting experience.

participants initial reactions to a short exposure to ostracism were not affected by two factors that would generally be regarded as rendering the ostracism experience meaningless: being ignored and excluded by a computer, and knowing that the players were told (or programmed) not to throw the ball to them.

although we do not have any measures to explicitly address this possibility, this suggestion would lead to an expectation of stronger effects under the scripted conditions (for human or computer sources), which we did not find.
for humans, it surely signals the potential for hard times, possibly loss of contact with important others, loss of resources, and in some cases, death.

hence, it appears that even the slightest hint of ostracism, in the present case by a computer, is enough to trip offemotional reactions that will activate coping strategies to increase ones subsequent inclusion.

in a variety of clever studies, nass and his colleagues have shown that humans will reciprocate self disclosures be more strategically polite, and form in-group alliances with computers, just as they have been shown to do with other people.
we remain motivated to find conditions that involve ignoring and exclusion but that are so minimal as to not inflict emotional damage.

based on the present findings, it appears that this search for the necessary and sufficient conditions for ostracism, at least when measured during or soon after the ostracism, may be difficult or impossible.
it appears that ostracism is such a powerful signal that even being ignored by a computer can activate strong reactions.

indeed, eisenberger, lieberman, and williams (2003) showed activation of the anterior cingulate cortex-the brain region that is also activated when individuals endure physical pain-as a result of cyberball ostracism, even when the participants were told their particular computer was not yet linked to the other two participants computers.

the amassed evidence suggests that at all levels of measurement, humans detect and suffer from the most minimal cues of ostracism, supporting our view that ostracism is such a powerful social signal that it produces widespread intrapsychic reactions that serve to mobilize coping responses (see also, panksepp, 2003).
previous research has found ostracism's immediate effects robust to moderation by individual differences.
however, this could be the result of using retrospective measures taken after the ostracism occurs, rather than assessing the effects of ostracism throughout the episode.
individual differences in loneliness and social avoidance and distress moderated affective reactions throughout ostracism and inclusion.
lonely individuals, compared to less-lonely individuals, had slower affect decrease when ostracized but quicker affective increase when included.
additionally, socially avoidant individuals recovered more slowly from ostracism than less-avoidant individuals.

introduction ostracism, being excluded and ignored, is a pervasive phenomenon that increases negative affect and threatens basic needs (i.e., belonging, self-esteem, control, and meaningful existence; williams, 2009).
ostracism is experienced neurologically as pain (eisenberger, lieberman, & williams, 2003), and hurts even when being ostracized by a hated outgroup (gonsalkorale & williams, 2007).
williams (2009) argues that humans evolved to detect the slightest cues of ostracism and experience immediate discomfort.

also, pedestrians who were given an ''air-gaze'' (i.e., having someone look in their direction, but not giving them direct eye-contact) by a passerby felt decreased social connection (wesselmann, cardoso, slater, & williams, 2012).
previous research suggests ostracized individuals may ''react first and ask questions later.''
ostracism's reflexive (immediate) effects appear insensitive to moderation by individual differences (williams, 2009).
however, extreme individual differences have shown moderation of ostracism's effects.

for example, ostracized participants with higher levels of personality traits symptomatic of cluster a personality disorders (i.e., discomfort with social interaction, severe interpersonal distrust, and/or detachment) self-reported experiencing a less aversive impact, compared to participants with lower levels of these traits (wirth, lynam, & williams, 2010).
another study demonstrated that elderly participants who were ostracized self-reported experiencing less aversive effects than younger ostracized participants (hawkley, williams, & cacioppo, 2011).
the difficulty researchers previously had finding moderation may lead them to conclude that individual differences do not moderate initial reactions to ostracism.
might it be the case that individual differences moderate ostracism's effects during the course of the ostracism episode but have little effect on individuals at the end of the episode?
without using methods that assess these questions, researchers may erroneously make conclusions that underestimate the dynamic nature of experiencing ostracism.
we argue certain individual differences may moderate ostracism's effects over time, and this can be detected by monitoring participants' second by second reactions during an ostracism episode.
a time-course measure of participants' reactions may allow for nuanced investigations of ostracism's reflexive effects, but without utilizing expensive biofeedback technology.
this approach may limit researchers from understanding the complex ways in which individual differences moderate ostracism's immediate effects.
these individual differences may moderate the overall magnitude of ostracism's effects, the speed at which participants are affected by ostracism, and the speed of recovery.
loneliness lonely individuals perceive that their current social relationships are inadequate, and they chronically experience feelings of isolation (cacioppo & patrick, 2008).
lonely individuals hunger for increased social connection and sometimes even an thro po morph ize non-social agents as a way to satisfy their need (epley, akalis, waytz, & cacioppo, 2008).
lonely individuals often experience a double-bind; they desperately want to be included, but tend to feel anxious and distressed about social situations (leary, 1990).

because of this bind, lonely people may become hyper-sensitive to social information, particularly exclusion relevant cues (cacioppo & patrick, 2008; carter-sowell, chen, & williams, 2006; gardner, pickett, jefferis, & knowles, 2005).
these studies suggest that lonely individuals should show more affective decline to ostracism over time than non-lonely participants because of their hypersensitivity to exclusion relevant cues.
lonely participants should also respond more positively to inclusion over time than non-lonely participants because their hunger for human connection is being satisfied.

one possibility is that individuals high in this construct, compared with those who are low, would be affected less negatively by ostracism because they already have a preference for avoiding others (similar to cluster a personality disorder, see wirth, lynam, et al., 2010).

alternatively, those individuals high in social avoidance and distress may have stronger reactions to ostracism over time because they are already going to be uncomfortable in a social situation - ostracism may compound their discomfort.

participants high in social avoidance distress should also have less positive affect when being included than participants who are low in social avoidance and distress because these individuals are distressed more by social interactions (watson & friend, 1969).
this approach permits a timecourse investigation of ostracism that is more sensitive for detecting moderation than using measures taken solely at the end of the interaction.

we expect to replicate previous research by demonstrating an overall main effect of ostracism, such that ostracized participants' affect will decrease over time, whereas included participants' affect will remain relatively stable.

we also hypothesize that when ostracized, more-lonely participants will show more affect decrease over time than less-lonely participants, and morelonely participants will also have more affect increase to inclusion over time than less-lonely participants.
we also hypothesize that participants high in social avoidance and distress will have less affect increase over time in response to inclusion than participants low in social avoidance and distress.

finally, we will use this time-course approach to explore the possibility that individual differences may influence the speed of affect decline in addition to overall change, as well as any effects on recovery.
these items were averaged, such that higher numbers represented more loneliness.
found no evidence that fear of negative evaluation (fne), another component of social anxiety, moderated the immediate effects of ostracism.
cyberball was designed as an ostracism experience in which participants perceive themselves to be ignored and excluded when they are not thrown the ball.
regardless of individual differences, ostracized participants' affective valence decreased significantly over time (time condition; see table 2 for statistics).
further, ostracized participants' affective decline leveled off by the end of the ostracism episode, and suggested that they may begin to recover given more time (curvature condition).
unexpectedly, included participants also changed over time, whereby affect dropped slightly during the latter half of the game but then improved towards the end.

all ostracized participants demonstrated affective decline, but over time participants high in loneliness showed less affect decrease than participants low in loneliness (time condition loneliness; fig.
included participants also demonstrated affective increase, with those participants high in loneliness demonstrating more affect increase than participants low in loneliness.
thus, the disparate impact of our ostracism manipulation was greater for individuals high in loneliness than for individuals low in loneliness; inclusion was better and ostracism was worse.

contrary to either hypothesis, ostracized participants high in social avoidance did not differ significantly in the magnitude of affect decline than those low in social avoidance (time condition social avoidance; fig.
the data do suggest that participants high in social avoidance and distress begin to recover more slowly than those participants low in this variable (curvature condition social avoidance).

we also examined included participants and found social avoidance and distress did moderate participants' response to inclusion (time condition social avoidance); participants high in social avoidance and distress felt less positively towards inclusion than participants low in social avoidance and distress.

participants' self-reports of feeling ostracized and their dial position at the end of the game were negatively correlated (table 1); the less positively participants felt at the end of the game, the more ostracized they reported retrospectively feeling during the game.
we used a continuous measure and found that individual differences in loneliness and social avoidance and distress moderated participants' experiences of both ostracism and inclusion.
lonely individuals had a more negative reaction to ostracism overall and also reacted more favorably to inclusion than less-lonely individuals.

personality and individual differences 53 (2012) 580-586 583 participants' affect decreased less rapidly than less-lonely participants' affect (as indicated by the curvature condition loneliness interaction).

a potential explanation for this is that lonely individuals have often come to expect being excluded from social interactions (cacioppo & patrick, 2008), so it may be less of a surprise to them when it actually happens.

the lack of significant moderation in this case does not necessarily mean that there is no influence of social anxiety on affect level over time, but this type of moderation may occur in a more extreme clinically anxious population.

we did find significant moderation in recovery from ostracism; the interaction between curvature and social avoidance and distress suggested that ostracized participants recovered more slowly than if they were high in social avoidance and distress compared to low (similar to zadro, boland, & richardson, 2006).

we also examined the included participants and found that participants high in social avoidance and distress had less positive affect when being included than participants who were low in social avoidance and distress.
unexpectedly, we found in general that ostracized individuals' affect levels began to rebound toward the end of the experience.

ostracized individuals' affect levels were still significantly below that of included individuals, but our interpretation of the regression estimates suggest that given additional time their affect would likely recover even more.
recovery from ostracism can be expeditious; some ostracized participants can recover within minutes after cyberball (wirth & williams, 2009).
we can estimate from our data that recovery may begin even during the ostracism episode itself.
future directions future research should investigate other individual differences that theoretically may moderate ostracism's effects during the episode.

this means that some individuals decline at a faster rate and others at a slower rate, even when controlling for loneliness and social avoidance, suggesting that there are other individual differences contributing to this variance.
ultimately, a number of individual differences may moderate the speed at which participants are affected by ostracism, how quickly affect levels may bottom out, and potentially the speed of recovery.

williams's temporal model of ostracism (2009) argues that humans evolved to detect minimal cues of ostracism because they could quickly attend to the source of the cues and make the necessary attributions to avoid permanent ostracism.

these cues may be detected quickly, but interpreting them as a viable threat to social status (compared to an indicator of friendly teasing; keltner, capps, kring, young, & heerey, 2001), may take additional time for interpretation.

future research could utilize our dial approach to examine how quickly individuals detect cues of ostracism, and if some individuals (e.g., those high in rejection sensitivity or self monitoring are quicker than others at detecting the first cues of ostracism.
some individuals may misperceive ambiguous social cues as ostracism (e.g., lonely individuals; cacioppo & patrick, 2008).
when social pain is not automatic: personality disorder traits buffer ostracism's immediate negative impact.
eye gaze as relational evaluation: averted eye gaze leads to feelings of ostracism and relational devaluation.

using cyberball, we examined how adolescents from different ethnic groups in the netherlands (of moroccan, turkish, and dutch descent with either muslim, christian, or secular beliefs) responded to being included or excluded by ethnic inand outgroup members.
we expected that exclusion by ethnic outgroup members would represent a categorization threat and would result in greater hostility.

we hypothesized that exclusion by ethnic ingroup members would represent an acceptance threat and would result in responses that reduce uncertainty and increase one's chances of being accepted by others (e.g., a stronger endorsement of fundamentalist religious beliefs).

the results revealed that among all ethnic groups, exclusion by ethnic outgroup members led to more hostility toward the co-players and the coplayers' ethnic group than exclusion by ethnic ingroup members.
this was mediated by the extent to which people attributed their exclusion to the racist attitudes of their co-players.
among muslims and christians, exclusion by ethnic ingroup members led to more support for fundamentalist beliefs.

today, almost two decades after solomos and wrench described how western european countries were grappling with the social integration of immigrants in the 1980s, concerns over tensions between immigrants and host majority populations have only become more prominent in europe.

after 9/11, outbreaks of ethnic and religious violence expressed by and at part of the muslim immigrant community have sparked concerns about increasing hostility between muslims and non-muslims, and have raised fears about religious radicalization among muslim youth.

according to many experts, muslim adolescents, many of whom are second or third generation immigrants, may be vulnerable to adopting more fundamentalist forms of faith because they feel excluded and rejected in their host societies, mostly by the host majority group but sometimes also by their ethnic ingroup.

majority group members, on the other hand, are believed to have become increasingly hostile toward the muslim community because they fear that muslims reject their way of life (e.g., buijs, demant, & hamdy, 2006; coolsaet, 2005; eumc, 2006; sageman, 2004).
nevertheless, it is not clear whether or when social exclusion or rejection leads to the polarization of ethnic groups and to religious radicalization.

although our manipulation affects both perceptions of being ignored and excluded (williams' definition of ostracism), we have chosen to use the term "exclusion" because it is a more familiar term to researchers and theorists who study intergroup conflict.
more specifically, we were interested in the possibility that such reactions may vary as a function of the status of those who exclude (i.e., ingroup vs. outgroup members).

furthermore, even though many discussions on religious radicalization focus on muslims, we wanted to examine whether similar processes might occur among members of different ethnic groups, and with different religious affiliations.

for this purpose, we examined how adolescents from different ethnic groups in the netherlands (of moroccan, turkish, or dutch descent with either muslim, christian, or secular beliefs) responded to being included or excluded by ethnic inand outgroup members.

following branscombe, ellemers, spears, and doosje (1999), we argue that such differential coping responses are likely to occur because exclusion by outgroup members constitutes a different threat to a person's social identity than exclusion by ingroup members.

whereas exclusion by outgroup members may represent a categorization threat (i.e., people may believe that they are the victims of prejudice or racism), exclusion by ingroup members is more likely to represent an acceptance threat (i.e., people may become uncertain about their position within their group).
exclusion and intergroup hostility human beings are deeply motivated to form and maintain positive relationships with others and to avoid exclusion (baumeister & leary, 1995).

being excluded - even for a few minutes - can be a painful experience (e.g., eisenberger, lieberman, & williams, 2003), which increases stress and anxiety and negatively affects people's self-esteem, their sense of belonging, their sense of control over social interactions, and their belief in a meaningful existence (williams, 2001).
to restore these needs, excluded people may respond with anger and hostility.

for example, laboratory studies have shown that excluded people are more likely to feel angry and to act aggressively toward other people, and less likely to act in prosocial ways (e.g., gaertner, iuzzini, & o'mara, 2008; twenge et al., 2001).
even though this is unlikely to improve social inclusion, it may help individuals to fortify needs of control and recognition (e.g., warburton et al., 2006).

there is evidence that being excluded or ignored is an unpleasant experience, regardless of whether it occurs by inor outgroup members (e.g., gonsalkorale & williams, 2007; williams, cheung, & choi, 2000).
nevertheless, there is also reason to believe that exclusion by ethnic outgroup members may evoke more hostile reactions than exclusion by ethnic ingroup members.

for example, in a study among black and white students in the usa, mendes and colleagues (2008) demonstrated that social rejection by different-race evaluators resulted in more anger (i.e., irritation, defensiveness) than social rejection by same-race evaluators.
these differential reactions may occur because people may interpret exclusion by ethnic outgroup members differently than exclusion by ethnic ingroup members.

several authors (e.g., mendes et al., 2008; williams et al., 2000) have argued that exclusion by ingroup members is likely to result in internal, self-blaming attributions, whereas exclusion by outgroup members is more likely to lead to external or grouplevel attributions.
this may be a threatening experience, particularly when people wish to be evaluated in terms of their individual characteristics
in such a situation, people may consider the exclusion as more unjust, and this may result in greater hostility toward those who exclude (e.g., branscombe, schmitt, & harvey, 1999).

for example, mendes and colleagues (2008) found that members of both minority and majority groups (blacks and whites) reported more anger following social rejection feedback from a different-race evaluator than from a same-race evaluator.
exclusion by ethnic outgroup members may evoke hostile feelings not only toward those who exclude, but also toward the outgroup as a whole.

for example, research on the intergroup sensitivity effect has shown that group-directed criticism from an outgroup results in more negativity toward the critic and toward the entire outgroup (e.g., amiot & hornsey, 2010).

studies on the optimal conditions of intergroup contact have found that positive intergroup contact may reduce this anxiety and lead to more favorable attitudes toward the outgroup (for an overview, see pettigrew & tropp, 2006).
we believe that this is particularly likely to occur because people will more readily attribute exclusion by ethnic outgroup members to prejudice and racism.

given that people generally want to maintain membership in their own group and also tend to evaluate ingroup members relatively positively (e.g., tajfel & turner, 1986), it seems unlikely that they will develop more hostile attitudes toward the ingroup following exclusion by ingroup members.

exclusion and religious fundamentalism it is also possible that, when their religious beliefs are an important part of their identity, people will endorse fundamentalist religious 830 j. schaafsma, k.d.

these truth claims and absolute moral principles may provide excluded people with a sense of certainty and may help them to regain their lost needs of control (e.g., friedman & rholes, 2007; greenberg, solomon, & pyszczynski, 1997; salzman, 2008).
moreover, fundamentalist beliefs may provide religious people with the possibility to construct meaning.

for individuals who have been excluded, this need to construct meaning may be particularly relevant because the exclusion may serve as a mortality salience cue: it may give them an idea of what life would be like if they did not exist (williams, 2007).
there is some evidence that human beings (unconsciously) manage the anxiety that results from this awareness of their vulnerability by relying on stable cultural worldviews.

for example, previous studies have found that individuals who have been reminded of their mortality tend to adhere more strongly to and defend their worldviews (e.g., greenberg, simon, pyszczynski, solomon, & chatel, 1992; greenberg, porteus, simon, pyszczynski, & solomon, 1995).

according to pyszczynski, solomon, and greenberg (2003), religious worldviews - and fundamentalist beliefs in particular - may even be among the most effective buffers against existential anxiety because they create a sense of psychological security and hope of immortality.
moreover, by living up to the religious standards of value, religious individuals can obtain the approval of relevant others and acquire a sense of value or self-esteem as well.

thus, they may also adhere more strongly to fundamentalist beliefs following exclusion as a way to regain their lost needs of belonging and self-esteem (e.g., pyszczynski, greenberg, & solomon, 1997; wisman & koole, 2003).

we believe, however, that the tendency among religious persons to endorse fundamentalist ideas more strongly following exclusion will also depend on whether they are excluded by ethnic inor outgroup members.

nevertheless, whereas we previously argued that people are likely to become more hostile following exclusion by ethnic outgroup members, we believe that they will endorse fundamentalist religious ideas more strongly following exclusion by ethnic ingroup members.

our primary rationale for this assumption is that exclusion by ethnic ingroup members is more likely to raise questions about one's acceptance by or position within one's own group and that it may as such represent an acceptance threat (branscombe, ellemers, spears, & doosje, 1999).

this lack of acceptance by ingroup members may be less easily diffused through the use of external attributions (as may be the case with outgroup exclusion), and it may therefore make people more uncertain about themselves.
according to uncertainty identity theory (hogg, 2000), people can try to do so by identifying more strongly with groups they already belong to.
research by hogg, meehan, and farquharson (2010) also suggests that self uncertainty strengthens identification with radical groups.
for this reason, we expect that religious individuals may deal with an acceptance threat by ethnic ingroup members by turning to their religion and to fundamentalist religious beliefs in particular.

there is also evidence that ethnic minorities feel less and less accepted in the netherlands and tend to withdraw into their own ethnic groups (e.g., gijsberts & dagevos, 2005; vermeulen & penninx, 2000).

in the past few years, an increasing number of moroccanand turkish-origin adolescents also appear to have become more susceptible to the call of orthodox islam (e.g., buijs et al., 2006; slootman & tillie, 2006).
we expected that the interactive effect of inclusionary status and coplayers' group status would be mediated by people's attributions to racism.

we hypothesized that exclusion by ethnic ingroup members would result in stronger fundamentalist religious beliefs among muslims and christians than exclusion by ethnic outgroup members (i.e., an interaction between inclusionary status and co-players' group status).

of these participants, 54 had to be excluded because they belonged to a different ethnic group, expressed suspicion regarding the cover story or were unable to correctly identify the ethnic background of their co-players.

we used fewer items than the original scale, because pilot testing indicated that participants often had a relatively short attention span and found it difficult to fill out lengthy questionnaires with seemingly redundant items.

a preliminary series of anovas with follow-up analyses revealed that participants' reactions to inclusion or exclusion varied primarily as a function of whether they played with ethnic inor outgroup members, rather than the specific ethnic group involved.

hostility toward co-players and toward co-players' ethnic group we examined whether exclusion by ethnic outgroup members evoked more hostility toward those who exclude than exclusion by ethnic ingroup members.

we also examined whether participants who had been excluded by ethnic outgroup members reported more hostile feelings toward the co-players' ethnic group than those who had been excluded by ethnic ingroup members.

hostility following exclusion: the mediating role of attributions to racism we expected that our participants would be more hostile following exclusion by ethnic outgroup members than following exclusion by ethnic ingroup members because they would be more likely to attribute the exclusion to racism.
mediated moderation occurs when the interaction between two predictors affects a mediator, which in turn affects an outcome variable.
as expected, people who had been excluded by ethnic outgroup members were more likely to attribute this to racism (m=3.53) than people who had been excluded by ethnic ingroup members (m=2.75).
in both analyses, we found that the two-way interaction between inclusionary status and co-players' group status was attenuated.
the indirect effect (e.g., the effect of the interaction term on the dependent variable through the mediator) is considered significant if zero is not in the 95% confidence interval.

thus, these findings confirm that the interactive effect of inclusionary status and co-players' group status on hostility toward the co-players and the co-players' group is mediated by people's attributions to racism.
support for fundamentalist religious beliefs we also analyzed whether exclusion resulted in more support for fundamentalist religious beliefs.
more specifically, we examined whether exclusion by ethnic ingroup members resulted in stronger fundamentalist religious beliefs than exclusion by ethnic outgroup members.

these results show that people's reactions to exclusion vary as a function of the social identity of those who are excluding them, and lend support to the idea that exclusion by ethnic outgroup members represents a different type of threat to a person's identity than exclusion by ethnic ingroup members.

furthermore, there was a marginal trend such that moroccan-origin participants who had been excluded by dutch co-players tended to support fundamentalist ideas less strongly (m=4.87) compared to those who had been included by them (m=5.20), f(1, 492)= 3.48, p=.063.

moreover, we found that people tended to have more hostile feelings toward outgroups than toward their ingroup, and that these hostile feelings were stronger among those who had been excluded by outgroup members.
in line with our expectations, we also found that differences in hostility following exclusion by ethnic inand outgroup members were mediated by attributions to racism.

persons who had been excluded by ethnic outgroup members were more likely to attribute this to racism than persons who had been excluded by ethnic ingroup members, and hence were also more likely to respond with hostility.
these results suggest that exclusion by ethnic outgroup members leads to more hostility because it represents a categorization threat (branscombe, ellemers, spears, & doosje, 1999).
that is, persons who were excluded by ethnic outgroup members may have felt that they were primarily being evaluated in terms of their group membership.

according to branscombe and colleagues, this may be a threatening experience, particularly when people wish to be evaluated in terms of their individual qualities or expect to interact on an interpersonal basis.

as a result, people who were excluded by ethnic outgroup members may have perceived the situation as more unjust or unfair than those who were excluded by ethnic ingroup members and responded with more anger or hostility.
this is noteworthy, given that it has often been argued that the effects of perceived racism or prejudice should be different for minority and majority group members.

for example, according to schmitt and branscombe (2002), members of disadvantaged groups are more likely to have experienced exclusion across a wide variety of contexts and may therefore be more sensitive to being treated negatively because of their group membership than members of privileged groups.
nevertheless, it is possible that people's reactions to outgroup exclusion depend on the extent to which they believe that one's ingroup deserves ill treatment.
if this is the case, then they may be less likely to attribute exclusion to racism, and they may feel less threatened by it.

our results also suggest that ethnic minority and majority group members' reactions to exclusion by outgroup members depend upon the intergroup context, and that under certain circumstances, both minority and majority group members may be anxious about being treated negatively because of their group membership.

thus, for the dutch-origin participants in our study, exclusion by turkish and moroccan outgroup members may have contributed to their fear that muslims want to impose their own norms and values on the broader dutch society.

given these circumstances, both minority and majority group members may have perceived of their exclusion by ethnic outgroup members as illegitimate or unjust and may have responded with anger or hostility.

exclusion and fundamentalist religious beliefs as expected we also found that, if religion was part of people's identity, exclusion by ethnic ingroup members resulted in more support for fundamentalist religious beliefs, whereas exclusion by ethnic outgroup members did not result in stronger fundamentalist religious beliefs.

these results lend further support to the idea that exclusion by ingroup members represents a different type of threat to a person's identity than exclusion by outgroup members, and may therefore result in a different coping response.

more specifically, exclusion by ethnic ingroup members may constitute an acceptance threat, which may make people uncertain about themselves, in particular because it may be less easily diffused through the use of external attributions than exclusion by ethnic outgroup members.

to reduce this uncertainty, people may be motivated to strengthen their ties with clearly defined and distinctive groups (e.g., fundamentalist religious groups), and to support the worldviews of these groups (e.g., hogg, 2007).

these worldviews may offer them protection because they create a sense of certainty and control, meet personal needs for meaning, and may help satisfy lost needs of belonging and selfesteem (e.g., hogg, adelman, & blagg, 2010; pyszczynski et al., 1997).

future studies should, however, examine more directly whether ingroup exclusion indeed results in more self uncertainty than outgroup exclusion, and whether this may explain why people become more attracted to fundamentalist religious beliefs.

it should also be noted that our finding that exclusion by ethnic outgroup members does not result in more support for fundamentalist religious beliefs seems to be inconsistent with previous research on the relationship between rejection and religious identification.

for example, verkuyten and yildiz (2007) found in a questionnaire study among turkish minority group members in the netherlands that they identified more with their religious ingroup when they perceived more rejection from the dominant outgroup.
that is, it is entirely possible that people strongly identify with a religion or a religious group, but do not support fundamentalist beliefs.
it is possible that people's reactions to exclusion of ingroup members are different from their reactions to being personally excluded.

so far, however, there was only limited empirical evidence showing that exclusion or rejection actually leads to more interethnic tensions or causes individuals to become more attracted to fundamentalist religious ideas.
the results of this study confirm that exclusion may result in intergroup hostility and may also lead to stronger fundamentalist religious beliefs.

williams / journal of experimental social psychology 48 (2012) 829-837 ethnic outgroup members is likely to result in more hostility than exclusion by ethnic ingroup members, exclusion by ethnic ingroup members is likely to result in stronger fundamentalist religious beliefs.
this challenges the generally held idea that exclusion by ethnic outgroup members will lead to more religious fundamentalism.

moreover, our finding that muslims as well as christians support fundamentalist beliefs more strongly following exclusion by ethnic ingroup members challenges the commonly held assumption that muslims in particular are susceptible to religious radicalization.
for example, we did not use the full religious fundamentalism scale because pilot testing indicated that participants had difficulty filling out lengthy questionnaires with seemingly redundant items.

furthermore, one should keep in mind that, even though excluded participants were more hostile toward their co-players and toward their co-players' group than included participants, they were not highly hostile in an absolute sense, with scores being below the midpoint of the scale.

for example, minority group members may lack the necessary confidence to engage in negative behavior toward majority group members, also because they are often dependent on majority group members for everyday life purposes (guinote, brown, & fiske, 2006; simon, aufderheide, & kampmeier, 2001).

despite these limitations, this study advances prior research on exclusion by demonstrating that, even though exclusion may be universally painful, people's reactions to it vary as a function of who is excluding whom and why.
moreover, this study is - to our knowledge - the first to demonstrate that exclusion can be a precursor to religious fundamentalism and to the polarization of ethnic groups.
understanding the root causes of these processes is important, because they have the capacity to disrupt the stability of society.

our findings suggest that, to effectively counter such processes, interventions should focus not only on the social integration of different ethnic groups in society at large, but also on their integration within their own communities.
when rejection by one fosters aggression against many: multiple victim aggression as a consequence of social rejection and perceived groupness.
