compared with inclusion, exclusion threatens people's fundamental needs, decreases their mood (blackhart, nelson, knowles, & baumeister, 2009; gerber & wheeler, 2009), and impairs self-regulation (dewall & baumeister, 2006).
exclusion also makes people feel colder than inclusion (zhong & leonardelli, 2008) and causes their brains to register higher levels of pain (eisenberger, lieberman, & williams, 2003).
more specifically, we assess whether people's psychological and behavioral reaction to inclusion or exclusion differs depending on the primary source of the actions leading to it.
although, generally, both will to some extent be a cause of inclusion or exclusion, we argue that either of these processes may be the predominant cause in a given situation.
at the one extreme, we argue, people may end up included or excluded primarily as a result of other people's actions.
for example, people may or may not be asked for their opinion, be kept in the loop of information, be asked to join a work group, or be invited to a birthday party.
although people may exert some effort to secure inclusion in these examples, ultimately others' decision on whether to include them determines whether this will happen.

people's own failure to "claim" inclusion in a computerized ballgame was equally detrimental for fundamental needs and made people equally unlikely to behave prosocially to group members, as being denied inclusion by others.
sometimes, exclusion may even be harshly enforced by collectively humiliating some individuals (schuster, 1996) or by giving them the silent treatment (gruter, 1986).
key in all these examples is that other people's actions play an instrumental role in causing a target's state of inclusion or exclusion.
that is, people end up included or excluded primarily because other people's actions cause their inclusion or other people's actions cause their exclusion.
at the other extreme, we argue, inclusion or exclusion may result primarily from people's own actions.
inclusion may also depend on meeting more implicit requirements, and people are highly sensitive to cues of such implicit norms.
indeed, people who are successful at meeting such explicit or implicit membership requirements end up included, whereas people who fail to do so end up excluded.
in other words, inclusion or exclusion primarily results from people's own success or failure to do what is necessary to ensure inclusion.
that is, people end up included or excluded primarily because their own actions cause inclusion or their own actions cause exclusion.
existing experimental research often focuses on inclusion and exclusion that result predominantly from the actions of others.

a substantive body of research has found that, compared with social inclusion, social exclusion makes people feel worse and threatens their fundamental needs for belongingness, self-esteem, control, and meaningful existence (blackhart et al., 2009; gerber & wheeler, 2009).

however, it remains unclear whether the observed effects are generally the result of the satisfaction of inclusion, the distress of exclusion, or both (blackhart et al., 2009; gerber & wheeler, 2009).
distinguishing between different sources of inclusion and exclusion may provide a useful framework in which to interpret the existing findings and understand why they occur.
we assert that, in addition, this will be the case no matter whether exclusion is based on one's own actions or on the actions of others.
as a result, rather than reacting in a reflexive and undifferentiated manner, people should be ready to appreciate differences in how they got included right from the start.
as a result, we argue that their reactions to inclusion will differ if it results from their own actions or those of others.
satisfying the need to belong may require having both ongoing interactions with a person and having a relationship marked by concern and caring (baumeister & leary, 1995).

in support of this view, studies of romantic relationships have found that inclusion fails to be satisfying when affective feelings are unrequited (baumeister, wotman, & stillwell, 1993) or relationships lack mutual concern (clark & mills, 1979).
claiming and being granted inclusion are equally viable ways of securing ongoing interactions.
after all, how one attains inclusion does not affect the frequency with which one interacts.

however, when one is granted inclusion, this may be perceived as a sign that one is appreciated, possibly even cared about, by interaction partners, whereas it seems difficult to attribute such feelings to interaction partners when inclusion is claimed for oneself.
for example, although prior research on ostracism generally finds that inclusion is not more or less moderated by cross-cutting variables than exclusion, there is one often overlooked exception.

zadro and colleagues (2004) studied whether it mattered if inclusion or exclusion was allegedly based on people's own decision to toss or not toss a ball to the participant, or whether they were simply following a script.
this difference did not impact people's immediate evaluation of exclusion, but it did impact people's immediate evaluation of inclusion.
when coplayers allegedly chose whom to toss the ball to, inclusion was more satisfying than when they followed a script (zadro et al., 2004).
in line with this reasoning, we contend that to offer maximum psychological benefit, inclusion needs to be granted by others rather than claimed for oneself.
thus, participants' inclusion or exclusion in the game allegedly results from other players' willingness to throw them the ball.

in other words, the computer determines the outcome of classic cyberball, but participants are led to believe that their inclusion or exclusion in the game results from the behavior of the other players.

a simple change to the instructions and procedure of the game, but not to its outcome, allowed us to compare the consequences of inclusion and exclusion when they result from other players' behavior and when they result largely from participants' own behavior.

to ensure the outcomes mirrored those of the classic cyberball game, the game was rigged such that participants in the inclusion condition managed to claim the ball as often as the other players, whereas participants in the exclusion condition only managed to get a couple of throws.

however, in claimball, participants are led to believe that their inclusion or exclusion in the game results largely from their own behavior, whereas in classic cyberball it allegedly results from the behavior of the other players.
we predicted that exclusion from claimball would have an equally negative impact on these fundamental needs as exclusion from classic cyberball.
moreover, we predicted that inclusion in claimball would not satisfy people's fundamental needs to the same extent as inclusion in classic cyberball.

simple effects analysis revealed that exclusion did not reduce need satisfaction relative to inclusion as strongly in claimball, f(1, 128) = 69.86, p < .001, η2 = .35, as in classic cyberball, f(1, 128) = 145.77, p < .001, η2 = .53 (see figure 1).
thus, as is typical for inclusion exclusion manipulations using cyberball (k. d. williams, 2007), being excluded versus included had a detrimental impact on all four fundamental needs.
stated differently, the differential impact of inclusion in classic cyberball and claimball was driven mainly by the need to belong and the need for meaningful existence.
for this purpose, we draw on recent insights that inclusion is associated with warmth.
for example, compared with exclusion, inclusion increases perceptions of room temperature and reduces people's longing for warm food and drinks (zhong & leonardelli, 2008).
we expect that the effect of inclusion on warmth will also depend on the antecedent process.

as giving is more strongly associated with warmth than taking (l. e. williams & bargh, 2008), we predict that participants who are included in classic cyberball will think their interaction partners perceive them to be warmer than participants included in claimball.
in line with this notion, we expect that people will react differently to inclusion depending on their perception of the level of warmth involved.

given that people prefer relationships marked by mutual affective concern (baumeister & leary, 1995), we expect that people will find inclusion in relationships more satisfying when their interaction partners perceive them to be warm.
thus, we expect that meta perceptions of warmth will mediate the effect of the different conditions on need satisfaction.

more specifically, we predict that participants who are included in claimball as opposed to classic cyberball will think their interaction partners feel less warmly toward them and as a result will experience lower levels of need satisfaction.
that is, we assess whether others benefit or suffer depending on the antecedents of their interaction partners' inclusion.
we argue that meta perceptions of warmth will also mediate the effect of claimed versus received inclusion on prosocial behavior.
again, we predict that participants who are included in classic cyberball will think their interaction partners perceive them to be warmer than participants included in claimball.

finally, to ensure that the effect on need satisfaction and prosocial behavior do not simply result from changes to participants' affective states, we tested whether mood acted as an alternative mediator.
thus, again being excluded versus included had a detrimental impact on all four fundamental needs in both games.
thus, again, similar to study 1, the differential impact of inclusion in classic cyberball and claimball was primarily driven by belonging and meaningful existence.

the immediate impact of exclusion was equally detrimental for people's fundamental needs, warmth, and prosocial behavior, regardless of whether the ball was not thrown to them or failed to be claimed by them.

when people managed to claim a ball as often as other players, their fundamental needs were less satisfied and they gave less to interaction partners than when they were thrown the ball as often as other players.

moreover, they thought others perceived them to be less warm, and this relative lack of warmth satisfied their fundamental needs to a lesser extent and made them less inclined to behave prosocially to interaction partners.
these results imply that the immediate impact of claiming rather than receiving inclusion is to significantly undermine its psychological and interpersonal benefits.
importantly, we provide evidence that the immediate impact of processes underlying inclusion and exclusion need not work in similar ways on the two ends of the inclusionary continuum.
we add that excluded people are equally hurt when it results from a failure to claim inclusion as when it results from being denied inclusion.
however, we show that people's immediate reaction to inclusion differs depending on whether people claim it or whether it is granted to them.

thus, one needs to assess reactions to both inclusion and exclusion to fully understand the immediate effects of the processes underlying inclusionary states as they do not always work in similar ways on the two ends of the inclusionary continuum (blackhart et al., 2009).
moreover, we found that inclusion needs to be accompanied by perceptions of warmth to have a strong effect on well-being.

this important finding is in line with the notion that both repeated interactions and interpersonal warmth are required to satisfy the need to belong (baumeister & leary, 1374 personality and social psychology bulletin 38(10) 1995).

however, people who were merely included as a result of a scripted procedure need not have assumed their interaction partner felt warmly about them, which may explain why prescripted inclusion was found to be less satisfying (zadro et al., 2004).
thus, we argue that prior research found that inclusion had similar psychological consequences under a wide range of conditions because these conditions did not differ in terms of warmth.

moreover, we observed that inclusion resulting from the actions of others had a more positive effect on overall well-being than inclusion resulting from one's own actions, whereas these antecedent processes did not affect the effect of exclusion on overall well-being.
however, this predicted interaction was only significant for the need for belonging, meaning, and control.
possibly, claiming inclusion did not reduce self-esteem relative to being given inclusion because self-esteem depends on feeling likeable as well as competent (tafarodi & swann, 2001).
thus, it is possible that claiming and receiving inclusion each boosted positive self-feelings in a different domain.
this underscores our reasoning that belonging remains a key motivation for people regardless of whether inclusion is largely the result of their own actions or others' actions.
indeed, although we observed that inclusion that is claimed is less satisfying for belonging than inclusion that is granted, it remained more satisfying than being excluded.
hence, our results speak against the possibility that people simply do not care about belonging when it results from their own actions.
although these questions are beyond the scope of our current focus on the consequences of claiming or being granted inclusion, they may offer a fruitful path for further investigations.

given that previous research found that exclusion by undesirable group members is no less painful than exclusion by desirable ones (e.g., zadro et al., 2004), we do not expect the value of the group to interact with the source (i.e., the self or others) of the exclusion.
the importance of interpersonal warmth for our findings suggests that the differential effects of claimed and received inclusion may depend on the value of the group.
participants may feel more warmly toward members of valued groups and thus react especially strongly to inclusion by interaction partners belonging to valued groups.

although beyond the scope of the current research, we note that participants in our studies may not necessarily have attributed their success or failure at attaining inclusion in line with the actions causing it.
they argued that people who were ignored should experience a failure to gain social connection, whereas people who were rejected should experience a loss of social connection.
the experiences of failing to claim inclusion and being denied inclusion might differ in a similar fashion.
thus, if they end up excluded, this ostensibly happens after they have attempted to claim the ball and failed.
consequently, they might primarily experience this as a failure at gaining inclusion rather than a loss of inclusion.
thus, extrapolating from the findings of molden and colleagues, they may be inclined to seek reengagement, which might also lead them to behave relatively prosocially.
in contrast, participants in classic cyberball need to receive the ball from other players to be included in the game.

as we expect that people will expect to be thrown approximately an equal proportion of the balls, we think that when this does not happen they will experience this as a loss of inclusion more than a failure to gain inclusion.

again extrapolating from the findings of molden and colleagues, this experience of exclusion should make them relatively more inclined to withdraw from the interaction, which might also lead them to behave relatively less prosocially.

we investigated the mediating role of meta perceptions of warmth (i.e., feeling perceived as well intentioned, warm, good natured) because of its implications for theorizing that both frequent interactions and a relationship marked by affective concern are required to satisfy the need to belong (baumeister & leary, 1995).
however, this does not mean that other variables might not also mediate the effect of inclusion on need satisfaction and prosocial behavior.

for example, participants in classic cyberball may infer that their interaction partners choose to include them because they ascribed positive qualities to them other than warmth (e.g., trustworthiness cooperative ness or competence) or might attribute equally favorable qualities to their interaction partners.
such variables might also mediate the effects of inclusion on need satisfaction and prosocial behavior, particularly in situations in which such positive qualities are valued.
assessing whether and when such differences occur may be a fruitful path for future research.
future studies might also assess the effects of over-inclusion, or appropriating a disproportionate number of ball throws.
this may result in more than a simple extrapolation of the current findings.
it is likely that claiming over-inclusion will be associated with less warmth than receiving it and, as a result, negatively impact well-being.

however, claiming over-inclusion might also have a positive effect on other important dimensions of social perception, like competence (fiske et al., 2006; wojciszke, 2005), which may increase well-being.
after all, being highly successful at claiming inclusion may make people feel victorious.
whether such an effect of competence on well-being will overrule our finding that warmth is essential for well-being remains an empirical question.
conclusion the broad implication of our results is that the lack of warmth associated with claimed inclusion as opposed to received inclusion reduces its psychological and interpersonal benefits.
thus, warmth is an indispensable part of belonging, suggesting that belongingness needs are only met if interactions are marked by a certain level of affectionate concern (baumeister & leary, 1995).
sadly, the people who crave belonging the most will be the most strongly motivated to try and increase it (baumeister & leary, 1995) and thus the most likely to revert to efforts to claim inclusion.
paradoxically, inclusion that people so effortfully try to secure for themselves may never quite be as satisfying or lead to equally prosocial behavior as inclusion that they effortlessly receive.
notes 1. as participants compete for inclusion in claimball, one might argue that when one succeeds at being included, this is because the other players were unsuccessful and vice versa.
thus, engagement did not moderate the effect of game type and game condition on fundamental needs, and does not offer an alternative explanation for our results.

although our analysis yielded only main effects on the mood composite, one might wonder whether exclusion from claimball exacerbates specific types of mood, in particular feelings of hostility or guilt.
when ostracism leads to aggression: the moderating role of control deprivation.
ostracism by a computer is sufficient to lower selfreported levels of belonging, control, self-esteem, and meaningful existence.
despite the minimal nature of their experience, the more participants were ostracized, the more they reported feeling bad, having less control, and losing a sense of belonging.
in study 2, ostracized participants were more likely to conform on a subsequent task.

recently, kraut and colleagues (kraut et al., 1998) reported that individuals who used the intemet for just a year or two were more likely to become depressed and lonely--a finding that to some was counter intuitive
nevertheless, kraut and colleagues argued that internet usage takes time away from face-toface contacts and replaces stronger ties with weaker ones.
as a result, the quality of interaction decreases, resulting in feelings of loneliness, depression, and generally a lowered sense of belonging.
this deleterious effect is further compounded when we consider observations that internet users often perceive that they are being ignored (rintel & pittam, 1997a, 1997b).
whether deliberate or not, one can only imagine the impact that being ignored may have on individuals who are using a medium that already predisposes them to depression and loneliness.

young children use forms of ostracism on each other during supervised play (barner-barry, 1986), and adolescents, particularly girls, are likely to use ostracism in their conflicts (cairns, calms, neckerman, & ferguson, 1989).
elderly citizens' reports of feeling ignored by society, colleagues, and family members are positively correlated with lower life satisfaction (madey & williams, 1999).

sweeting and gilhooly (1992) reported that loved ones and health care professionals had been observed to cease interacting socially with dying persons, often discussing postmortem tasks and responsibilities with others in the dying person's presence, as if they were not there.
research on ostracism its prevalence across time, cultures, and species has led to an increased interest in ostracism.

ostracism was viewed as evolutionarily functional for the sources (it kept the group cohesive and made it more likely to survive) but devastating to the targets (who usually died or were forced to join other groups).
in fact, the basis of many phenomena in social psychology resides in the assumption that individuals fear exclusion, rejection, and being ignored.

because of this fear, individuals conform, comply, obey, ingratiate, improve their appearance, and manage their impressions to others in order to be included and feel like they belong (baumeister & leary, 1995).
research on social ostracism has shown that it causes a host of psychologically aversive reactions in targets of ostracism.

the aversive impact of social ostracism has been shown to increase when targets attribute the ostracism to their own personal shortcomings (dittes & kelley, 1956; nezlek, kowalski, leary, blevins, & holgate, 1997; pepitone & wilpizeski, 1960) or when the ostracism is done more blatantly than subtly (snoek, 1962).

being ignored or rejected produced negative self evaluations even when individuals merely imagined (craighead, kimball, & rehak, 1979; samolis, 1994) or role-played being ostracized (williams, bernieri, faulkner, gada-jain, & grahe 2000; zadro & williams, 1998).

targets of social ostracism usually feel less positively about the sources who ostracized them (geller et al., 1974; pepitone & wilpizeski, 1960), but when the opportunity is presented, they often try to get back into the good graces of the sources (snoek, 1962; williams & sommer, 1997).

although there may be a common thread to these widely divergent phenomena, the model restricts the definition of ostracism to acts of being excluded and/or ignored, subjectively defined from either the sources' or targets' perspective.
it can be perceived when unintended, attributed to mundane explanations (as might occur when one is not acknowledged in an elevator) or to reasons that are more strategic and punitive.

unintentional ostracism may be perceived to be relatively meaningless (e.g., "the other person did not hear me") or extremely self-relevant (e.g., "the other person thinks so little of me as to not notice my existence").
because of the many ways to interpret such acts, we believe ostracism is rather unique in terms of its inherent ambiguity.
because silence usually accompanies being ignored, these questions are left unanswered.

ambiguity by itself has been shown to be aversive (edwards, 1998; grieve & hogg, in press; lieberman, cathro, nichol, & watson, 1997), but when linked to ostracism, it can lead to damaging introspections and attributions.
when attributions for ostracism can reflect plausibly on the self, it can be even more aversive, because it has the potential to threaten fundamental needs.

the core of the model is the proposition that ostracism, compared with other aversive interpersonal behaviors, uniquely and quickly threatens four fundamental needs: belonging, self-esteem, control, and meaningful existence.
ostracism deprives targets of their sense of belonging, because all signs of bondedness are severed.
ostracism is not simply disagreeing with targets or pointing out their shortcomings it is an active denial of being connected with the target.
furthermore, because ostracism is associated with punishment, it carries with it the implicit accusation that the target has done something wrong.
implicit negative feedback, perhaps especially when it is not linked to any specific behavior, should threaten targets' sense of selfesteem.
ostracism threatens targets' perceived control over the interaction with the source(s).
although exchanging verbal accusations or punches with sources is unpleasant, they can still provide the target with a sense of control or influence over the interaction.
a sense of control is lost when targets are unable to elicit any reactions from sources.
like other forms of mortality salience, ostracism should threaten people's sense of meaningful existence and remind them of the fragility of their lives.

as a result of these threatened needs, targets of ostracism are hypothesized to react initially with psychological discomfort, including negative mood, anxiety, physiological arousal, and hurt feelings.
williams's (1997) model proposes that, to defend against this psychological discomfort, individuals will cope by attempting to regain or refortify their lost or threatened needs.

for example, threats to belonging can be refortified by selectively remembering group information (gardner, pickett, & brewer, 2000), reminding oneself of groups to which one belongs, intensifying the love one has for others, or conforming to group norms (baumeister & leary, 1995).
whereas prior research has focused on the impact of physical and social ostracism, we believe that perceptions of exclusion and ignoring can also occur in virtual reality.
cyberostracism may be more or less frustrating and debilitating than social or physical ostracism.

it has the potential to be more ambiguous (e.g., what appears to be ostracism may be intended or it may reflect a technological problem) and it lacks useful cues usually available to targets in faceto-face interactions that might help clarify the situation.

on the other hand, the ambiguity might offer the target a nonthreatening excuse for being ignored (e.g., a technological difficulty), and the paucity of cues may allow the target enough anonymity and distance to deflect any possible effects of being ignored.
accordingly, in experiment 1, we hypothesize that targets of cyberostracism will report lower levels of belonging, self-esteem, control, and meaningful existence.

in experiment 2, we hypothesize that when targets of cyberostracism have the opportunity to cope with their psychological discomfort, they will be more likely to conform to others as a means to refortify their sense of belonging.

previous laboratory research (williams & sommer, 1997) indicated that in a relatively short and seemingly innocuous face-to-face triadic balltoss interaction, participants who were not thrown the ball readily perceived being excluded and felt bad compared with participants who were included.
although partial ostracism may produce doubts and frustration, it could also be misperceived and dismissed.
complete ostracism, however, should leave participants with no plausible interpretation other than that they are being excluded.
another reason for varying quantity of ostracism is that it allows us to eliminate an alternative explanation.
being a target of ostracism may be unpleasant simply because the individual feels conspicuous or self-aware (carver & scheier, 1981).
being included as an equal partner in a triadic tossing game would not make the participant feel conspicuous.
we felt that being the object of inattention was not the same as being the object of attention, so we hypothesized that overinclusion would not be aversive, whereas ostracism would be.
our general prediction for quantity of ostracism was that greater amounts of ostracism would lead to stronger aversive reactions.

research on rejection sensitivity of people low in selfesteem led us to test whether, compared with those higher in self-esteem, low self-esteem individuals would experience greater negative impact to ostracism relative to inclusion.
for instance, schneider and turkat (1975) reported that low self-esteem individuals were more dependent on the evaluations of others in determining their sense of self-worth.
baldwin and sinclair (1996) found that low self-esteem individuals held negative cognitive schemata that predisposed them to interpret socially ambiguous responses as rejection.

found that individuals who had either scored low on trait self-esteem or high in depression tended to feel less accepted when they believed they were personally rejected by others in the group but more accepted when they were personally included by the group.

thus, we predicted that there would be a main effect for self-esteem, such that lower levels of self-esteem would lead to higher levels of aversive impact, but we also were looking to see if self-esteem would interact with quantity of ostracism.
if lower self-esteem predisposes individuals to perceive negative feedback, then they should be more likely to perceive and react negatively, even with partial ostracism.
finally, based on our theoretical model, we expected that the effect of ostracism on self-reported psychological discomfort would be mediated by the degree to which the four needs were threatened.

according to baron and kenny (1986), mediation occurs if the independent variable predicts the dependent variable, the independent variable predicts the mediator, and the mediator predicts the dependent variable controlling for the independent variable in the model.
the model proposes that ostracism (the independent variable) can threaten each of four needs (the mediators), which in turn, lead to psychological discomfort in individuals (the dependent variable).

because belongingness and self-esteem were moderately correlated, (r = .59, p < .01), we investigated the extent that belongingness and self-esteem were unique mediators in the relationship between ostracism and aversive impact.
the regression analysis revealed that belongingness (/3 = 3.3, se = .12) and self-esteem (/3 = 1.24, se = .12) significantly predicted aversive impact (bothps < .001).
thus, they both appear to uniquely contribute to the relationship between ostracism and aversive impact.
although perceived control and meaningful existence were not influenced by the quantity of ostracism, they independently influenced aversive impact.
aversive impact, as measured by negative mood, intensity of ostracism, and low group cohesiveness, increased as ostracism became more complete.

these negative consequences were obtained despite the fact that, because participants were accessing the internet in their own private environments, they were insulated from public embarrassment and ridicule.
this result points to the strength and potency of ostracism; it can be felt even in the artificial and minimal social environment that we created over the internet.

this finding suggests that the need for belonging is particularly sensitive to even remote social cues, adding further support to baumeister and leary's (1995) claim that the need to belong is fundamental to human motivation.

other studies using social ostracism (i.e., ostracism by others who are in the presence of the target) have found that both control and meaningful existence are negatively affected (lawson williams & williams, 1998; williams, shore, & grahe, 1998; williams & zadro, 1999).
the lack of effects for these two needs in this study may be because they are not as relevant during cyberostracism, or at least during a brief period of cyberostracism.
perhaps the issue of control is less salient when we sit and watch the other players continue their exclusive interaction on the screen as compared with watching them in one's own presence.
it is also possible that participants experienced some control even in the ostracism conditions because they had to click the word next to continue the game.
and, meaningful existence may only be implicated by the feeling of invisibility (the death metaphor) that targets get when others present do not appear to see or hear them.
of the four needs, threats to meaningful existence may be the slowest to engage.
it is also possible that because our measures for control and meaningful existence were worded more abstractly (almost as traits), they were less sensitive to momentary changes.

baumeister and leary (1995) argued that the need to belong, defined as frequent, affectively pleasant, and stable interactions with a few others, is a powerful and extremely pervasive human motivation.

baumeister and tice (1990) postulated that human beings function to minimize social exclusion by engaging in achievement oriented behaviors (demonstrating their ability and willingness to contribute to the group) as well as by accommodating to group standards.
one way to accommodate to group standards is to conform to group judgments.
according to williams's (1997) model of ostracism, targets' reactions to short-term ostracism involve the desire to fortify needs that were threatened or deprived.
because cyberostracism reduced participants' sense of belonging in experiment 1, they should desire to reestablish bonds with other individuals.

therefore, by arranging the experimental task such that participants have the opportunity to make perceptual judgments following the unanimously incorrect judgments of five other individuals, we hypothesize that, compared with individuals who were previously included, targets of ostracism will be more likely to conform to the group norm.
we also examined whether the behavioral consequences of ostracism are greater if psychological ties between the targets and the sources are stronger.
we hypothesized that targets of ostracism by ingroup members will conform more than targets of ostracism by out-group members.

in support of this, reicher (1984) found that individuals endorsed attitudes that showed greater conformity to their own group norm than to an out-group norm during a discussion on the topic of vivisection.

more recently, mackie, gastardo-conaco and skelly (1992) found that whereas prior knowledge of the in-group position produced acceptance of the in-group position regardless of the message quality (i.e., even for non membership relevant messages), messages from an out-group source produced almost no attitude change.
from an attributional standpoint, self-blaming attributions should be greatest when individuals are ostracized by in-group members.

when ostracized by out-group members, targets may easily diffuse the negative impact of ostracism through the use of external, group-level attributions (e.g., "they are not throwing me the ball because of something about them, or because i am not in their group").

ostracism by in-group members should be less easily attributable to differences in group membership, resulting in more internal self-blaming attributions (e.g., "they are not throwing me the ball because of something about me personally"), which should have greater aversive impact on targets.
we believe that ostracism by a mixed-group will be threatening, although to our knowledge there are no studies examining mixed-group influence.
when ostracized by a mixed-group, targets may be less likely to attribute the ostracism to group membership, because even the in-group member is excluding them.
perceptions of betrayal by the in-group member may also be particularly keen, and the reason for being ostracized becomes very ambiguous.
therefore, targets may be led to make more internal, self-blaming attributions for the ostracism (e.g., "i am such a loser that my in-group member is choosing to conspire with the out-group member.")
our prediction then, is simply that ostracism by a mixedgroup will be as threatening and unpleasant as ostracism by ingroup members.

rather than giving targets the opportunity to conform to (or deviate from) the ostracizing group, we tested their likelihood of conforming to a new group that they would have no particular reason to impress or offend.
not only did targets of ostracism report lower levels of belonging (as they did in experiment 1), but they were also more likely to conform to the unanimous incorrect judgments of a new group.
thus, consistent with our theory, individuals reacted to a short-term episode of ostracism by refortifying the need that was threatened belonging by conforming to a new group.

it was conceivable that inclusion could have decreased conformity, because these individuals had already experienced sufficient inclusion to remove any attractiveness associated with conforming to another group.

in other circumstances, it might have been reasonable to expect included participants to have increased their levels of conformity, but we believe this would have only made sense if the subsequent perception task had been performed with the group that had included them.
these findings also lend support to the notion that ostracism serves to promote normative behaviors in the targets (gruter & masters, 1986).

at an evolutionary level, gruter and masters (1986) argued that the use of ostracism is adaptive because it maintains the cohesiveness of the group, either by removing the deviant member(s) or by bringing deviant members back into the fold.
the results are also consistent with schachter's (1959) speculations that isolation will increase affiliative tendencies.
the results of this study provide suggestive evidence that ostracism is a process that works similarly across species.
we also examined whether the relation between participants and their sources affected their perceptions of exclusion, sense of belonging, and subsequent conformity.
we predicted that participants who were ostracized by out-group members would be less affected than those who were ostracized by in-group members.

the sole exception was the in group ostracism condition, in which participants reported receiving the ball about as often (29%) as would be expected if they were equally included (33%), when in fact they only received the ball 20% of the time.

the inconsistency between the conformity results on the one hand, and the inclusion and belonging measures on the other hand, suggests that participants who were ostracized by in-group members were affected by the ostracism but did not want to admit it, to us or maybe even to themselves.

it is also possible that by simply being categorized in an in-group, participants felt more included, which may have reduced perceptions of intragroup distinctions, as suggested by our belongingness data.

according to social identity theory, we would have expected that individuals ostracized by in-group members would have been more threatened, and hence would have conformed more, than individuals ostracized by out-group members.

therefore, belonging should not mediate conformity in the way that it mediated aversive impact in experiment 1. two of baron and kenny's (1986) three criteria were satisfied: the independent variable, ostracism, significantly affected the proposed mediator, belonging; and ostracism significantly affected the dependent variable, conformity.

when we operationally defined conformity as the percentage of participants who conformed at least once, the pattern was then such that participants ostracized by in-group or out-group members showed similar percentages of conformity.
thus, regardless of how conformity was operationally defined, being ostracized by out-group members was just as effective in producing conformity as being ostracized by in-group members.
perhaps ostracism by anyone is sufficiendy aversive to trigger efforts to increase one's belongingness status, especially to a new group.

had we examined how likely participants would have been to conform to those who ostracized them instead of how likely they were to conform to a new, unfamiliar group, perhaps the social identity prediction would have been supported.
the mixed-group participants accurately reported the level of exclusion, reported lower levels of belonging when ostracized, and had high levels of conformity.
perhaps as long as there are out-group members in the ostracizing group, targets of that ostracism are less likely to distort or disguise what actually happened.
until now, the deleterious effects on targets have been observed when the sources of ostracism are physically present with the target--what we call social ostracism.

in the two experiments reported here, we have demonstrated that the impact of ostracism is so powerful that it can even be felt when two ostensible sources ignore and exclude individuals over the intemet.
when participants were cyber ostracized their sense of belonging and inclusionary status was reduced.
this, in turn, worsened their mood and increased their feelings of exclusion, and in study 2, cyberostracism increased participants' likelihood to conform.

it is rather astounding that despite the fact that our participants did not know, could not see, could not communicate with, and were not anticipating future interaction with "virtual others," they felt ostracized when these others neglected to throw them a virtual disc or ball.

on the one hand, we found in experiment 1 that ostracism was just a s debilitating to high as to low self-esteem individuals, and in experiment 2 we found that ostracism increased conformity regardless of whether the ostracizers were in-group members or not.
apparently, ostracism was powerful enough to overwhelm these typically potent personality and situational variables.

on the other hand, the pattern of results in experiment 2 suggests that perhaps with stronger manipulations of group identification or greater experimental control to reduce variability, identification with the ostracizing group may result in stronger effects.
ostracism was hypothesized to threaten targets' fundamental needs, including belonging, self-esteem, control, and meaningful existence.
with our internet paradigm, we found evidence that cyberostracism negatively affected feelings of belonging and selfesteem, but we found no impact on reports of control or meaningful existence.
furthermore, the model predicts that when fundamental needs are threatened by short-term ostracism, targets will try to repair, regain, or fortify these threatened needs.

hence, because belonging was threatened in experiment 1, we predicted and found that targets of ostracism would attempt to regain a sense of belonging by conforming to a new group when the opportunity arose.
however, internet participants may be less concerned with social desirability than participants who we meet face-to-face, because they may be less concerned with evaluation.

if participants used their real e-mail addresses, we were able to check for multiple access (there were only a few instances of repeated access, and these were primarily participants whose computers disconnected before they could finish).

a more serious problem is that we had exceptionally high dropout rates, especially in experiment 2. this suggests that the results may have been due to self-selection, such that only the types of people who would continue on with the experiment would give this pattern of results.
it is just as plausible, however, that individuals who were most bothered by the ostracism would have dropped out, thus, making our findings of reactions to ostracism more conservative.
whereas one participant may be alone in a quiet office during his or her lunch break, another may be at a public access terminal in a crowded and noisy internet caf6.
in this regard, internet research is a bit more like field research, in which large numbers of potential participants might offset the noise in the data.

finally, regarding ethics, al760 williams, cheung, and choi though internet research can provide written debriefing with handy links to the researchers' e-mail addresses, debriefing may be more effective if the researchers can see participants' faces and respond to their nonverbal behaviors (cooper, 1998).
in these classic studies, the researchers anticipated that they were developing baseline conditions that would likely not result in significant impact on their participants' behaviors.

they were all surprised that, even in their baseline conditions, people conformed to clearly wrong answers, developed senses of "we and they," and obeyed authority figures to the point of hurting someone.
instead, we found that people were so sensitive to being ignored and rejected that they showed negative reactions even in our baseline conditions.
perhaps, as with the impact of unanimous others, minimal groups, and legitimate authorities, ostracism may be an exceptionally potent form of social influence.
we have argued that short-term ostracism results in fortification of the threatened needs.
in contrast, we predict that for long-term ostracism, targets will internalize the threatened needs, resulting in feelings of depression, alienation, helplessness, and worthlessness.

she said her selfesteem plummeted as a result of his continuous use of this cyber silent treatment.
feelings of loneliness and depression are a possible outcome of continued internet usage.
as our global society moves closer to worldwide use of the internet, opportunities for exacerbating these feelings through real or perceived ostracism clearly exist and demand our attention.

after playing cyberball, the victimized students in the ostracism condition scored significantly lower on feelings of meaningful existence compared to the ostracized students not involved in bully/victim problems.
these results strongly support the idea that previously victimized students are more affected by experiences of social exclusion than students who are not involved in bully/victim problems.

keywords cyberball, victimization, bullying, social exclusion the experience of being victimized and systematically rejected by peers has profound consequences for the victims (alsaker, 2012; olweus, 1978; perren & alsaker, 2006).

one of the possible consequences of episodes of victimization, that has not received much attention yet, might be that victims become much more vigilant of potentially threatening situations and also show more pronounced reactions to single episodes of rejection or exclusion.
this, in turn, could increase the likelihood for a previous victim to become a target of further bully attacks.

against this background, the aim of the present study was to examine whether self-reported previous victimization moderates the aversive psychological and affective consequences of a well-defined, experimentally induced episode of social exclusion.
rug gier i psy uni be ch responded more negatively to being excluded from a ball-tossing game (cyberball: williams, cheung, & choi, 2000) than their non-victimized peers.

state of research bullying has been described as a subtype of aggressive behavior (olweus, 1978; 1996), in which an individual or a group of individuals (called bullies) repeatedly and systematically attack, humiliate, or exclude a peer (called a victim) who cannot easily defend him or herself (olweus, 1978; 1996).

bullying takes many different forms of negative actions, ranging from physical abuse (e.g., hitting, kicking) and verbal abuse (e.g., name-calling) to more subtle forms like isolation and social exclusion from a group.

it has been repeatedly argued that subtle acts of aggression should always be included in the definition of bullying in order to fully grasp this phenomenon because the act of bullying is aimed at humiliating the victim and always has a psychological component (alsaker, 2004).
as a consequence, social exclusion is known to be a common and powerful tool to bully peers.

the need to belong is central and fundamental to humans (bastian & haslam, 2010; baumeister & leary, 1995) and the act of being excluded from a group generates strong feelings of social pain and distress (williams, 1997; 2001).

moreover, it is associated with depression (gazelle & ladd, 2003), low self-esteem (leary, tambor, terdal, & downs, 1995), poor academic achievement (graham & juvonen, 1998), and dropping out of school (graham & juvonen, 1998; juvonen & gross, 2005; rubin bukowski parker 2006).

in fact, experiments have shown that social exclusion threatens four fundamental needs: sense of belonging (zadro, williams, & richardson, 2004), self-esteem (zadro et al., 2004; williams et al., 2000), sense of meaningful existence (williams, 2001, 2007) and control (williams et al., 2000).
even though social exclusion has devastating consequences for the victims, it is sometimes still dismissed as a harmless rite of passage or as an inevitable part of growing up (alsaker, 2012).
this is especially true for single incidences of social exclusion (or bullying in general), which are occasionally described as non-dramatic or even trivialized (alsaker, 2012).
however, in particular, children with a longer history of school victimization may be extremely sensitive to single episodes of exclusion.

individuals differ in how they process information about acceptance and rejection (downey & romero-canyas, 2005; zadro, boland, & richardson, 2006), and based on their previous history victims might have developed particular cognitive affective networks (w¨olfer & scheithauer, 2012).
in a major study, rosen, milich, and harris (2007) found that students who were identified as victims were much more likely to report frequent victimization.

moreover, a history of victimization was associated with a significantly higher degree of arousal with regard to the victimization narrative task, as well as greater difficulty in regulating emotions in high stress social situations (e.g., online ball tossing game).
rosen and colleagues (2007) concluded that victims identified with the role of victim and seemed to internalize their victimization experiences into their implicit selfconcept.
overall, there is evidence indicating that students who have a history of victimization and students who had not been involved in bully/victim problems respond differently to social exclusion.

second, within the ostracism condition, we expected the victimized students to report significantly lower scores for all four needs (h2a) and a less positive mood at posttest compared to students not involved in bully/victim problems (h2b).

it was important to restrict the analyses to these two categories because the two subgroups of victims - passive victims and aggressive victims - exhibit a different behavioral pattern (alsaker, 2004, olweus, 1978; perren & alsaker, 2006).

aggressive victims are victims who act aggressively themselves and therefore show a pattern of behavior that is typical for both victims and bullies (alsaker, 2004; olweus, 1978; perren & alsaker, 2006).
for ethical reasons, students who were assigned to the ostracism condition were invited to play cyberball in an inclusion condition before leaving.

more specifically, we examined whether self-reported victimization moderates the aversive psychological (need-threat) and affective (mood) consequences of an experimentally induced episode of exclusion.

extending previous research, the most important finding of the current study was that victims of bullying responded more sensitively to being excluded in terms of lower mood levels and feelings of less meaningful existence.
meaningful existence is about feeling that one's life has a purpose and that this purpose is recognized by others.
compared to self-esteem, i.e., how one feels about oneself, meaningful existence focuses more on the mechanisms through which these feelings are formed.
the items assessing meaningful existence may therefore better capture the core issue of social exclusion as well as the central mechanism of bullying in general.
psychological well-being is at least partly dependent on the perception that one is valued by others (pyszeczynsky, greenberg, & solomon, 1997).
therefore, the well-being of victims may be especially disturbed by systematic and repeated bullying attacks.

in fact, alsaker (2012) has argued that the discrepancy victims perceive between their suffering and the trivialization expressed by others triggers feelings of not being a valuable person, or as williams puts it, not having a meaningful existence (williams, 2001).

this experimental study lends support to these assumptions by showing that the perceptions and feelings of victims are profoundly damaged and that their negative feelings may be easily activated even in virtual ostracism situations.
mood was also more affected from short episodes of social exclusion in students who view themselves as passive victims.
individuals differ however in how easily their mood is affected through such events.

mood is generally less affected in adults t we nge bau meister tice stucke, 2001; zadro et al., 2004) and adults have also been described as more stable compared to children and adolescents (larcom & isaacowitz, 2009) indicating that self-confidence and stability might moderate the impact of unexpected events on mood.
this in turn might explain, why passive victims, who seem to be generally less self-confident and less stable (alsaker, 2006; boulton & smith, 1994) are more strongly affected by negative events.

in general our findings suggest that being victimized may bias how subsequent exclusion situations are interpreted and being victimized may be associated with lower rates of recovery (because the devastating episodes are experienced repeatedly).
in a similar vein, zadro and colleagues (2006) reported that highly anxious adults (mean age 22 years) recovered more slowly from the effects of exclusion compared to non-anxious participants.

in line with the finding that frequently experienced victimization might lead to incorporating the role of "victim" into one's social schemas (rosen et al., 2009), our results showed that students who perceive themselves as victims responded more intensively to a short episode of social exclusion.

single episodes of victimization that might seem harmless for teachers and for other students, would activate the cognitive affective network in the victim who perceives the "minor incidence" more negatively.
consequently single incidences of victimization should be seen as adding burden to a history of victimization.
it often happens that victims of bullying change class or even school.
however, our results suggest that changing the situation might not be the appropriate action.
the history of victimization remains unchanged and the cognitive affective networks of victims might put them at risk to become a victim in a new situation.
today, researchers agree that bullying constitutes a serious risk with respect to the psychological, social and academic adjustment of victims (buhs, ladd, & herald, 2006; hawker & boulton, 2000).

overall, the present study has demonstrated that although the aversive experience of exclusion may be universal, whether or not we recover from the experience may be moderated by victimization history.

given the detrimental consequences of ostracism, those who are vulnerable or particularly susceptible to ostracism (e.g., victims of bullying) need to be identified early in order 1) to stop the victim's suffering, and 2) to stop negative cycles of exclusion, interpretations and expectations.
previous studies have found that many teachers ignore and passively support bullying behaviors (alsaker, 2012; salmivalli, 2010; stassen berger, 2007).
it is possible that teachers do not recognize the severity of bullying.
in fact, cohn and canter (2002) reported that 25% of teachers see nothing wrong in bullying and intervene in only 4% of bullying incidents.
likewise, teachers often indicate that they intervene if they perceive the situation as serious (newman, 2011).
in fact, acknowledging the severity of bullying is the basic assumption for keeping the eyes open.
unless bullying is acknowledged as disrespectful and unfair, teachers (and other witnesses) will not be motivated to recognize bullying and implement intervention measures.

in summary, teachers first need to recognize the severity of bullying and the significance that a single incidence represents for the victims in order to recognize it when it happens and take responsible actions to stop it.
our results emphasize that taking single episodes seriously may be especially important for victims of bullying who already show a history of rejection and exclusion.
second, social exclusion is a common and powerful form of bullying and differs from other forms of bullying.

unfortunately, due to the lack of visible scars in social exclusion, people often think that the victim is exaggerating since there is no visible trail for others to follow (alsaker, 2012; nordgren, banas, & macdonald, 2011).
however, researchers agree that it is not necessary to be physically harmed in order to suffer lasting harm (alsaker, 2012; nordgren et al., 2011).
by abrams et al., 2011 and sebastian et al., 2010 in that the participants received the ball more often before the exclusion episode started, and the total length of the episode was shorter.

we predict that when concealed, the illogical aggressive response to rejection is more likely, whereas when the rejected individuals' aggressive responses are perceived as public, the aggressive acts may be reduced.
across experiments, when the opportunity to aggress was made public, rejected participants exhibited less aggressive behavior.
when concerned about the perception of their public aggressive responses by others, rejected individuals' aggressive responses diminished compared with those whose actions were private.
crucially, this extended to aggression visible only to neutral others, suggesting that effects cannot solely be due to fear of retribution.
impression management theory further proposes that individuals actively manage their public self to create and maintain a social image (schlenker, 1980, 1982; tedeschi & norman, 1985).

indeed, several experiments have indicated that people are motivated to enhance the self's public, and not private, image in order to appear desirable and important to others (baumeister, 1982; baumeister & jones, 1978).
other evidence suggests that people will try to improve their public image to such a great extent that they would even endanger their own lives (leary, tchividjian, & kraxberger, 1994).

and in fact, the importance of public image may be bonafide from an evolutionary perspective, as one's standing and social acceptance may have directly impacted one's chances of survival in the past (e.g., acceptance versus rejection from a social group leading to tangible benefits).
taylor & francis the journal of social psychology 2017, vol.
an implication of this theory is that publicness should not only reduce aggressive behavior, but that publicness of aggression may increase the seeking of social ties (e.g., prosocial behavior).

even laughter can trigger feelings of rejection when the target feels rejected by said laughter; in fact, such exclusion has been shown to result in greater temptations to aggress (klages & wirth, 2014).

although there are conflicting results, a mix of evidence suggests that in some situations, prosocial behaviors or behaviors that may result in increased social connection (e.g., obedience, riva, williams, torstrick, & montali, 2014) can be a result of rejection (for a review, see williams & warburton, 2005).
the aggressive response to rejection appears illogical and maladaptive, because it may encourage further rejection rather than acceptance.
that is, people (other than perhaps the experimenter him or herself) would be largely unaware of the rejected individuals' aggressive reaction.
however, the rejected participants were instructed to cover the allotted hot sauce, thereby maintaining the privacy of the aggressive act.
for instance, twenge and her colleagues (2001) demonstrated that, following a rejection experience, participants provided harsher ratings of the rejector's suitability as a laboratory assistant.
the aforementioned experimental results clearly demonstrate the relationship between rejection and subsequent aggression, but this link may be limited to relatively private acts of aggression.
thus, despite theoretical support for such a proposition, it is unclear which circumstances lead to aggression (or lack thereof).
it therefore remains to be seen whether or not rejection the journal of social psychology 65 leads to similar increases in aggression when others are aware of the aggressive act.

as such, when people feel that their acceptance by others is threatened by an act of rejection, they may be particularly likely to seek social connections (baumeister & leary, 1995; maner, dewall, baumeister, & schaller, 2007).
this may lead individuals to be less likely to aggress publicly, for fear of appearing socially undesirable.

impression management of aggression because people (especially rejected people, baumeister & leary, 1995) are motivated to seek acceptance from others, acting aggressively in front of others may not be an effective strategy of regaining lost social connections.
indeed, according to impression management theory, people will present themselves positively to gain social rewards (tedeschi & norman, 1985).

thus, rejected individuals who want to regain the liking of others should try to ingratiate themselves to others in an attempt to demonstrate a positive identity as likeable and worthy of acceptance (tedeschi & reiss, 1981).
reacting aggressively in public would not serve impression management goals, but rather it may undermine one's likelihood of being accepted by others (schlenker, 1986).

because people tend to avoid aggressive individuals, as this behavior is deemed unpleasant, becoming aggressive after rejection would likely decrease social appeal (smith & frohm, 1985; smith, pope, sanders, allred, & o'keefe, 1988).

in sum, becoming publicly aggressive in response to rejection would be a maladaptive strategy for rejected individuals to pursue, because acting aggressively may limit their potential relationships with others.

this suggests that the aggressive response to rejection may be more prevalent when the individual believes that a relationship with the rejectors is impossible or that they can seek revenge without risking future relationships with others.

if rejected people think that being aggressive will lessen the opportunity to create relationships with either the rejectors, or neutral third-parties (more likely, given that the rejector has already suggested that a relationship is unlikely), they may temper their aggression.
thus, when others are aware of the rejected individuals' reactions, they should avoid responding aggressively to the rejection.
even though research has clearly demonstrated a strong link between rejection and aggression, we propose that this effect is limited to private forms of aggression.
more specifically, we suggest that less aggressive responses to rejection may be exhibited when the aggressive act is made public as opposed to kept private.
socially rejected individuals who have the opportunity to aggress publicly may limit their aggression as a result of self presentation al concerns.
thus, although private aggression may remain high for rejected individuals, more public displays of aggression should not.

overview of current research whereas rejection typically increases aggression, we hypothesize that when the opportunity to respond aggressively is made public, rather than kept private, rejected participants will lessen their aggression.
in one condition, participants were led to believe that their aggression would be exposed to others and potentially linked back to them.

this comparison allowed us to evaluate participants' motivation to maintain positive relationships with neutral parties, as opposed to the possibility that its effect could solely be explained by fear of retribution.
based on impression management theory, we predicted that people would be more likely to respond aggressively when the aggression is not known to others than when the aggression is public.

given that these rejected participants were aware of the "other" participants' desire to become research assistants, and knowing that lower ratings would hurt the person's chances, this was deemed an aggressive act.
lower acceptance ratings indicate greater feelings of rejection provided by self-report in response to the question "i feel accepted."
lower ratings of the other participant indicate higher levels of aggression.

nonetheless, in line with our predictions for the manipulated variable of interest, these analyses indicate that participants were generally more aggressive when they believed that their ratings would be kept private.
discussion these results suggest that the extent to which an aggressive act is made public may affect how aggressively a rejected person acts.
that is, when the aggressive act is made public, individuals who have been rejected may not act as aggressively as if the aggressive act was kept private.
this suggests that aggressive responses to rejection are more likely to occur when they are not likely to affect the chances of forming relationships with others.

one limitation of this experiment is that participants in the public condition believed that both the other participants and the experimenter would witness their aggressiveness, whereas participants in the private condition thought their ratings would be entirely anonymous.

thus, participants in the public condition may have been less aggressive because they feared retaliation from the target of their aggressiveness (i.e., the other participants) and not because they were concerned that other people (i.e., neutral parties such as the laboratory staff) would witness their aggressiveness.
participants were led to believe that, in order to reduce experimental bias, the experimenter was unable to decide how much hot sauce to give each of the participants.

as in previous research (e.g., lieberman et al., 1999), the amount of hot sauce placed in the cup was used as a measure of aggression, because the other participant had clearly indicated a dislike for hot sauce on their (fabricated) taste preference inventory and would be made to consume it.

thus, in the public condition, both the cup type and the verbal reminder made it clear that the experimenter and the "other" participant would be aware of the any aggressive act (e.g., amount of hot sauce the "other" participant would be forced to consume against their wishes).

thus, in the private condition, while the "other participant" would still be aware of the act of aggression, by appearances, no neutral third parties (e.g., experimenter or research staff) would be aware of the aggression.

however, unexpectedly there was an interaction for perceived rejection, f(1, 51) = 4.10, p = .048, ηp 2 = .074. yet, this interaction is difficult to interpret and may be spurious because feeling rejected was rated after both the rejection and the public manipulations.
greater amounts of hot sauce indicate higher levels of aggression.

the means and standard deviations for these analyses are displayed in table 2. discussion the results of this experiment support the prediction that rejected individuals will temper their aggression if they believe that their aggressive act will be seen by others.

critically, in the private condition of experiment 2, the rejectors would know that they were aggressed against (once they tasted the overly spicy food), but the neutral third party would not know of the aggressive act.

thus, the reduced aggression in the public condition was not due to a fear of retaliation (which would be the same in the private condition) but rather a concern about how the neutral third party would perceive the aggressive act.
participants likely held back their aggression because they were engaging in impression management.
furthermore, the results of experiment 2 suggest that making the aggressive act public will reduce aggression for rejected individuals (as opposed to accepted individuals).
this suggests that giving excessive amounts of hot sauce was a deliberate aggressive act, designed to hurt someone who had previously rejected the participant.
general discussion the results from the current investigation suggest that the aggression that often follows rejection may be tempered when the aggression is made public to others.
in experiment 1, socially rejected participants were kinder in their ratings of a target if they believed others would see their ratings.
this effect was replicated in experiment 2-rejected participants allocated less hot sauce to a target when they believed that their hot sauce allocation would be visible to others.
therefore, it is unlikely the aggression was tempered due to fear of retaliation.
instead, rejected participants restrained their aggression because they knew neutral third parties would know of their behavior.
this was true when they felt they could do so without negatively impacting their future social outlook.
critically, however, they publicly avoided aggressing when either the guilty rejectors (experiment 1) or other parties (experiment 2) might witness the aggression and develop a poor impression.

in the present experiments, the aggressive response exhibited by rejected individuals was dependent on whether neutral third parties would know about their aggression, not on whether their aggression was traceable by the aggression target (the rejector).
in other words, people are willing to aggress after being rejected if they think there is no way for others to know about the aggression (see maner et al., 2007 for a similar argument).

thus, the aggressive act is limited to conditions when relationships with others are not being pursued or are not going to be further damaged, including potential relationships with either the rejector or with neutral third parties.
specifically, our studies suggest that when aggression opportunity is made public, rejected individuals will limit their aggression.

thus, previous research on rejection and aggression may have overstated the relationship between rejection and aggression as a result of ignoring instances when the opportunity to aggress is made public.
clearly, being rejected negatively affects one's inclusionary status as well as one's self-perception (e.g., self-esteem; bernstein et al., 2013).
following such an experience, individuals may be particularly likely to seize opportunities to gain acceptance by others.
acting aggressively would likely thwart this motivation by reducing the chances of being subsequently accepted by the witnesses of the aggression (smith & frohm, 1985; smith et al., 1988).

thus, consistent with the theory that in private settings, controlor existence related needs leading to aggressive actions may overpower needs that typically (and in public settings) affect behavioral reactions to rejection (e.g., belongingness and self-esteem needs; williams & warburton, 2005).
our results demonstrate that the public awareness can mitigate the typical aggressive reactions to rejection.
furthermore, our findings are consistent with previous research indicating that reactions can differ based on construal of the situation (e.g., smart, richman, & leary, 2009).
in the current investigation, participants demonstrated less aggressiveness when their aggression would be witnessed by others.

although the reason why they behaved this way was not explicitly tested in these studies, consistent with these theoretical explanations, it seems likely that rejected individuals did not want to appear aggressive so they could avoid being rejected again by other people.
for example, it is possible that rejected people thought logically about aggressing in front of others, and after weighing their options, concluded that aggressive action would be detrimental.
alternatively, the knowledge that others would know about their aggression may have lessened their feelings of hostility.
clarification the journal of social psychology 73 of these underlying processes may improve our understanding for why rejection causes people to become privately, but not publicly, aggressive.
that is, it is unclear how participants in our rejected, public aggression conditions would respond if they were given a subsequent opportunity to aggress privately.
perhaps by limiting their aggression when others are watching, the desire to aggress dissipates.
alternatively, it is possible that suppressing the desire to aggress only leads to a stronger aggressive impulse that would be acted on in a subsequent, more private context or in a more passive way.

furthermore, it remains unclear how results would differ if rejected participants were given the opportunity to engage in prosocial acts immediately after rejection (rather than the opportunity to aggress, as in the current work) in public versus private circumstances.

the current results suggest that perhaps the effect of making the prosocial reaction public may not enhance prosocial acts for accepted individuals, yet there may be a difference for rejected individuals.
across two experiments, we found consistent evidence that rejected participants temper their aggressiveness when their aggression is made public as opposed to kept private.
thus, it appears that rejection does elicit aggression, but that this response depends on whether there are witnesses to the aggressive act.
