causal_sentence: ostracism by a computer lowers belonging, control, self-esteem, and meaningful existence.
belonging to social groups serves an important role in shaping our social identities.
nonetheless, research indicates that exclusion by ingroup and outgroup members seems equally aversive.

the current studies test the hypothesis that unlike more trivial groups (e.g., smoking or computer preferences), highly essentialized groups may lead to differential effects of ingroup versus outgroup rejection.
consistent with this, exclusion and inclusion by racial ingroup members (relative to racial outgroup members) exacerbated the sting of rejection and the glow of inclusion (study 1).
these results offer a novel demonstration that essentialized in group out group distinctions enhance the sting of social exclusion and the positivity of social inclusion.

the ability to establish and maintain social connections has numerous benefits: groups provide social support, access to important resources, protection from environmental dangers, and access to potential mates (buss, 1990, 1991; duncan et al., 2007).
indeed, baumeister and leary (1995) argue that it is so vital to our survival that it counts as one of our basic human needs, along with sustenance and shelter.
because of the importance of belonging, a great deal of research has focused on reactions to being included and excluded by social groups.
despite the manifold downstream responses to social rejection, one clear and consistent result emerges: people have a strong, negative, visceral emotional reaction to being socially rejected.

moreover, rejection elicits decrements in the fulfillment of a constellation of factors that k. d. williams and colleagues refer to as four "basic needs": belongingness, self-esteem, perceptions of control over the environment, and perceptions of leading a meaningful existence (e.g., k. d. williams & zadro, 2005).
moreover, such rejection induced decrements in these basic needs are surprisingly resilient to moderation by individual differences (see k. d. williams, 2007).
perhaps more remarkable is that these effects on mood and need fulfillment appear equally strong, regardless of the rejecting source.
even rejection by a nonsocial actor appears to have the same effects as rejection by a social actor.
in all cases, the negative emotional consequences of social rejection are experienced as equally aversive, regardless of the nature of the rejecting party.

in a particularly surprising display of the apparent invariance of reactions to rejection, gonsalkorale and williams (2007) found that being rejected by a hated outgroup felt just as negative (i.e., had the same deleterious effects on mood and basic needs) as being rejected by a positively evaluated ingroup.

surprisingly, regardless of who the excluding party was, participants' responses were equivalent; rejection was equally painful regardless of whether the rejection came from an ingroup, an outgroup, or even a despised outgroup.

in a comprehensive model focused on responses to social rejection, k. d. williams (2007) argues that immediate reactions to social exclusion are reflexive and virtually immune to moderating influences.
williams asserts that this reflexive response to rejection is due to the extreme importance of actual or possible social rejection.

from this perspective, because rejection is such a potentially dangerous threat, the immediate flash of negativity and insult to basic needs are equivalently strong, regardless of who is doing the rejection.

outgroup members, on the other hand, are less accurately remembered (bernstein, young, & hugenberg, 2007), elicit more avoidance behavior (shah, brazy, & higgins, 2004), and are deemed less trustworthy (voci, 2006) than comparable ingroup members.
given this strong and ubiquitous ingroup bias, there is good reason to believe that rejection by valued ingroups should be more painful than rejection by outgroups.

maximal groups: essentialism one possible explanation for why past research has failed to moderate the experience of rejection via ingroup and outgroup distinctions may be that the groups employed in this research were not impactful enough for participants.
indeed, attitudinal groups such as computer and smoking preferences may be relatively mundane group distinctions.
even political parties, although clearly stronger affiliations, may lack the punch yielded by more chronically meaningful groups (brewer, 2004).
on the contrary, it may be that more maximal groups are needed to qualify the effects of rejection.

in short, groups that are (a) ubiquitous in daily life and functionally affect the distribution of resources and (b) seen as biologically essentialized should yield more powerful effects than the attitudinal groups used in past work.

perceiving an outgroup as essentialized is one of the core components of prejudice (allport, 1954; haslam, rothschild, & ernst, 2002; keller, 2005) and acts as a means of justifying inequalities between groups (jost & banaji, 1994; sidanius & pratto, 1999).

as beliefs about the essential nature of a group increase, attention to stereotype consistent as opposed to inconsistent information increases (bastian & haslam, 2007) along with endorsement of those stereotypes (bastian & haslam, 2006).
other research has shown that essentialized outgroups are actually seen as less human; they are denied human emotions only attributed to ingroup members (leyens et al., 2000; leyens et al., 2001).
thus, we propose that previous research has not found a link between ingroup or outgroup status and the intensity of rejection experience because it has not used these essentialized maximal groups.

the current research using this logic, we hypothesized that being rejected by a member of an important and essentialized ingroup should feel worse (i.e., more strongly threaten basic psychological needs) than being rejected by an outgroup member sharing those same characteristics
conversely, being included by a maximal ingroup member should feel better (i.e., more strongly fulfill basic needs) than being included by a maximal outgroup member.
in two studies, we provide novel evidence that the positivity of inclusion and the negativity of exclusion are more potent when they stem from these maximal ingroup members.

study 1 manipulates the race of confederates who include or exclude participants with the hypothesis that same-race inclusion and exclusion would show exacerbated effects relative to cross-race inclusion and exclusion.
such essentialized social categories appear to exacerbate the effects of stereotyping (hoffman & hurst, 1990), prejudice, and other important intergroup effects (e.g., brewer, 1986).

for example, m. j. williams and eberhardt (2008) found that conceiving of racial group membership as being biologically essentialized led to increased approval of racial inequity and, perhaps more important for the current investigation, led to a disinterest in possible interactions with racial outgroup members.
they argue that individuals see racial outgroup members as irrelevant to the self and unworthy of affiliation when the race of the outgroup members is seen as essentialized.
this allowed us to independently manipulate whether participants experienced social inclusion or exclusion brought about by members of a racial ingroup or a racial outgroup.

if race is a maximal group, and such in group out group distinctions affect the experience of being rejected and accepted, rejection by a racial ingroup member should hurt more than rejection by a racial outgroup member.
similarly, acceptance by a racial ingroup member should feel more positive than acceptance by a racial outgroup member.

in short, we predict that manipulating this maximal ingroup and outgroup status (i.e., avatar race) should elicit the in group out group × acceptance rejection effects that have not been observed in previous research.

being accepted by an important and essentialized ingroup would feel better, and being rejected by an 1002 personality and social psychology bulletin 36(8) important and essentialzed ingroup would feel worse, than identical treatment by an outgroup member.
participants in the maximal condition were led to believe that political affiliations were unchanging, biologically based, and affected multiple dimensions of life.
we predicted that in the control condition, only a main effect of social rejection should occur, replicating gonsalkorale and williams.
we hypothesized that although rejection by a racial outgroup member would still be experienced as negative (k. d. williams, 2007), rejection by a racial ingroup member should hurt even more.

conversely, while acceptance by a racial outgroup member should feel good and should fulfill basic belongingness needs, we hypothesized that acceptance by a racial ingroup member would feel even better still.

in short, racial distinctions in the united states are maximal groups, an in group out group distinction we predict should moderate the effects of social inclusion and exclusion on mood and basic belongingness needs.

specifically, after exclusion experiences, participants reliably report lower levels of belonging, lower perceived control over their environment, lowered selfesteem, and the belief that they lead a less meaningful existence (for a review, see k. d. williams, 2007).

participants were led to believe that because this study was being conducted simultaneously by multiple departments at the university, they would be playing with other university students located throughout the campus.
results and discussion consistent with past research, it was expected that social exclusion would threaten individuals' basic needs, whereas social inclusion would satisfy the needs.
our prediction, however, was that this main effect of inclusionary status would be qualified by an interaction with the ingroup and outgroup status of the avatars.

inclusion by racial ingroup members should bolster individuals' basic needs more than being included by a racial outgroup member; conversely, exclusion by a racial ingroup member should lower basic needs more than exclusion by a racial outgroup member.

thus, in line with k. d. williams's (2007) argument, we hypothesized that inclusion or exclusion by outgroup members would still affect basic needs; however, we hypothesized that these effects would be exacerbated by a shared maximal ingroup membership.
although exclusion always hurts, it appears to hurt somewhat less when it comes from a racial outgroup.
conversely, the experience of inclusion is always good, but it is experienced as especially positive when it comes from a racial ingroup.

past research and theory have indicated that initial reactions to social exclusion and inclusion on this same index of basic belongingness needs appear unconditionally automatic and thus insensitive to moderation (e.g., k. d. williams, 2007).
however, the current results suggest that when accepters or rejecters are members of essentialized ingroups, the subjective experience may be magnified, for better and worse.

although study 1 provides novel evidence of moderation of the basic needs based on the racial ingroup or outgroup membership of others who exclude or include participants, they do not clarify why race serves as a moderator of these effects.
indeed, as it was used in study 1, race likely confounds multiple psychological phenomena.
employing a direct manipulation of the essentialized nature of political affiliations affords multiple benefits.
first, political affiliation is the same category distinction used in gonsalkorale and williams (2007), who found that group status did not moderate the effects of social exclusion.

thus, if as we predict, gonsalkorale and williams found null results because participants believed this group distinction to be unimportant and malleable, we should replicate that null in our control un essential i zed condition.

instead, if the inclusionary status × ingroup/ outgroup interaction occurs only in the maximal condition, not in the control condition (wherein political affiliation is believed to have no essentialized basis); this would provide direct support for our maximal group hypothesis.

participants were told: "members of political parties share deep-seated attitudes, and although someone may occasionally vote for a candidate of a different party, political affiliation tends to be a life-long thing," and "political tendencies are like being left-handed or right handed you're born feeling more natural using one hand or the other."

however, for those in the maximal condition (highly essentialized), we predicted that exclusion should feel worse for ingroups than for outgroups whereas inclusion should feel better for ingroups than for outgroups.
this directly replicates the findings from gonsalkorale and williams (2007) as well as previous studies, all showing that group status does not moderate the powerful effects of social exclusion.

thus, as predicted, group status did moderate the effects of social exclusion or inclusion on individuals' basic needs but only under circumstances where individuals believed the groups to which they belong are essentialized.

general discussion in two studies, we found support for the hypothesis that the effect of social exclusion and inclusion on individuals' basic needs is moderated by the ingroup and outgroup relationship between the interacting parties, but only for groups considered essentialized.
inclusion is more fulfilling to one's basic belongingness needs when it comes from an ingroup as opposed to an outgroup member, and exclusion by an ingroup feels worse than exclusion by an outgroup.

although we replicated the previous literature indicating that rejection threatens basic needs and inclusion fulfills them, these effects were moderated by the ingroup or outgroup status of participants' ostensible interaction partners.

these findings are consistent with our hypothesis and, to the best of our knowledge, represent the first demonstration that the ingroup and outgroup relation between interactants moderates the immediate effects of rejection on belongingness need fulfillment.
moreover, in study 2, we manipulated perceptions of essentialism directly, leading participants to believe political parties were or were not essentialized group distinctions.
nonetheless, when participants were led to perceive political groups as having an essentialized basis, the effect of inclusionary status on basic needs was moderated by ingroup and outgroup status.
this serves as seminal evidence that group status can moderate the effect of social exclusion or inclusion on the fulfillment of basic psychological needs.
we have argued that the essentialized nature of the groups themselves plays an important role in these effects.
such central groups may be perceived to afford great potential benefits when they accept us yet may pose greater perceived danger when they exclude us.

the previous research documenting unmoderated effects of exclusion on individuals' basic needs levels relied on preference groups, such as computer, smoking, or political preferences, whose membership and effects may be more ephemeral.

insofar as race plays a central role in identity, in social interaction, and in the distribution of resources in a society, this more potent group distinction may elicit more potent effects as documented in our first study.
although some categories (e.g., race) are seen as inherently biologically essentialized, essentialism can also be manipulated.

thus, many groups can be made to be seen in a more or less essentialized manner and thus elicit the stronger feelings associated with inclusion or exclusion found in our second study that utilized political party affiliation.

essentialized groups are seen as more highly entitative (brewer & kramer, 1985) and may be more likely to elicit stronger responses due to the heightened category salience and perceived immutability (brewer, 2004; hoffman & hurst, 1990).
essentialized ingroups are more important to our social identifies whereas essentialized outgroups warrant less attention and less desire for affiliation (m. j. williams & eberhardt, 2008).
as a consequence, it seems that only more essential groups should lead to the moderation documented in our studies.
despite the fact that ingroup and outgroup status qualifies the effects of inclusion and rejection, we interpret our findings as a true testament to the power of social rejection.

rejection is such a fundamental threat to social survival that even when rejected by groups generally unimportant to most of our social lives (e.g., computer use preference), we nonetheless still feel the pain of the experience.
across both of our studies, inclusion and exclusion by outgroup members had a clear and potent effect on basic need fulfillment.

their model identifies that individuals confronted with social rejection respond with an automatic, reflexive reaction to the experience, which makes individuals aware of their threatened needs and prepares them for action (k. d. williams, 2007; k. d. williams & zadro, 2005).
in this model, social rejection is experienced as a sort of physical pain meant to alert individuals to the dire situation they may be facing (eisenberger & lieberman, 2005).
inclusion and exclusion even from outgroups elicit basic needs effects.

nonetheless, we believe the current work does provide novel evidence that at least some in group out group distinctions are sufficiently important to make both the pain of exclusion and the joy of inclusion more poignant.
nonetheless, in neither study did the match or mismatch between participant sex and avatar sex interact with social inclusionary status to effect participants' mood and basic needs.
we believe this is true because sex operates very differently than do most in group out group distinctions.
unlike most group distinctions, men and women form collaborative rather than competitive relationships to meet shared goals such as mating and child rearing.
finally, and perhaps most importantly, sex does not create an ingroup bias.
this powerful effect, known as the "women are wonderful" effect, leads individuals of all types of backgrounds to evaluate women more positively than men (eagly & mladinic, 1989).
thus, insofar as the ingroup magnifies inclusion and exclusion in part because we like the ingroup, sex is one in group out group distinction that should not elicit such effects.
we also believe that this research may lead to important questions about how behavioral outcomes differ following social exclusion by essentialized or nonessential i zed ingroups and outgroups.
given the findings in this article, we believe it is possible that such behavioral outcomes may be enhanced, but perhaps not attenuated, by perceived essentialism.
perhaps rejection by any group will elicit antisocial or prosocial responses to some degree, but when being rejected by an essentialized ingroup, the responses are magnified.

this has the dangerous implication that ingroups seen as most essentialized will be the groups that elicit both the most prosocial acts from rejected members and the most serious and consequential acts of aggression and violence.

given the prevalence of aggressive acts such as school shootings, perhaps victims of social exclusion do not only see their victims as being high in entitativity (see gaertner & iuzzini, 2005), but perhaps they also see them as being essentialized.

if this is the case, then breaking down perceptions of entitativity might not be enough to decrease aggressive responses against the entirety of groups who have engaged in rejection, so long as the victims of it still see the groups as having traits that are inborn, immutable, and everlasting.
we see no reason to believe that the effects of perceived essentialism on rejection are so fickle as to vanish in the presence of others.
groups are essential to human survival, but some groups are more essentialized than others.
it appears, then, that these ingroup and outgroup distinctions do matter when it comes to inclusion and exclusion.
however, it is a testament to how powerful the threat of rejection must be when only the most important of group distinctions can moderate the effects of rejection.
even then, rejection by outgroups is still experienced as a threat to one's most basic psychological needs.
the current evidence suggests that although rejection is a painful experience in all cases, some experiences of rejection and acceptance are felt more keenly than others.
this change was performed simply to allow for more variability in participant responses in study 2.
effects of social exclusion on cognitive processes: anticipated aloneness reduces intelligent thought.
social rejection initiates an adaptive response when discriminating among real and fake smiles.
the crosscategory effect: mere social categorization is sufficient to elicit an own group bias in face recognition.
getting a cue: the need to belong and enhanced sensitivity to social cues.
social ostracism by one's coworkers: does rejection lead to loafing or compensation?
ostracism by a computer is sufficient to lower self-reported levels of belonging, control, self-esteem, and meaningful existence.
as belonging increased, so did the desire to listen to emotional disclosure.
however it did not increase the desire listen to descriptive disclosure.
in this investigation, we tested the belongingness hypothesis - which is that the need to belong motivates people to listen to their friends disclose emotional, but not descriptive, information.
study 1 reveals that the need to belong is associated with wanting to listen to friends' emotional, but not descriptive, self disclosures

they reveal that increased belonging needs, and not differences in mood and self-esteem, were associated with an increased desire to listen to friends disclose emotional, but not descriptive, information.

consequently, we know that people regularly disclose their emotional experiences with close others, such as friends (rimé, 2009), and that emotional disclosure generates greater feelings of social connection than other types of self-disclosure (espitalier, tcherkassof, & delmas, 2002; laurenceau, feldman barrett & pietromonaco, 1998).

even though people are typically disclosing such information with one or more listeners (gable, reis, impett, & asher, 2004), emotional disclosure has been studied to a lesser extent from the perspective of the listener.

the belongingness hypothesis is that the need to belong motivates people to listen to their friends disclose emotional, but not descriptive, information as a means to increase their own feelings of social connection.
that is, as belonging needs increase, people are more likely to want to listen to their friends disclose emotional, but not descriptive, information.
listening to emotional disclosure promotes a sense of social connection.

for instance, listening to others talk about emotions more generally (peters & kashima, 2007) and positive events in particular, promotes feelings of closeness between the speaker and the listener (gable et al., 2004; reis et al., 2010).
typically the more emotion that is disclosed, the more intimacy is generated (laurenceau et al., 1998).

listening to emotional experiences also stimulates conversation, because listeners tend to share the emotional narrative with journal of experimental social psychology 49 (2013) 915-921 ⁎ corresponding author.

listening to other people's emotional narratives consolidates bonds between group members (christophe, di giacomo & amatulli, submitted for publication), helping to further build and maintain interpersonal relationships (curci & bellelli, 2004).
listening to other types of information such as descriptive disclosure, on the other hand, may not promote the same degree of social connection.

find that, after taking into account the effects of listening to emotional disclosure, listening to descriptive disclosure does not increase feelings of closeness between the speaker and the listener.
in sum, it may not be listening in general, but listening specifically to emotional disclosure that increases feelings of social connection.
indeed, people often disclose emotional information to strengthen their social bonds or degree of connectedness with others (rimé, 2009).
likewise, people may listen to emotional disclosure, because doing so likely generates feelings of connectedness for the listener, as well as for the speaker.
if so, then when people's need to belong (baumeister & leary, 1995) is threatened, they may be especially motivated to listen to emotional disclosure to fulfill this need.

the need to belong and listening the need to belong is a fundamental "drive to form and maintain at least a minimum quantity of lasting, positive, and significant interpersonal relationships" (baumeister & leary, 1995, p. 497).
in other words, feeling socially connected is essential to human functioning.
the psychological and physical costs associated with a lack of belonging attest to its pervasiveness.

people who don't have frequent positive contact with others feel anxious (baumeister & tice, 1990), lonely (peplau & perlman, 1982), depressed (leary, 1990), and angry (williams, shore, & grahe, 1998).
they are more likely to engage in self-defeating behavior (twenge, catanese, & baumeister, 2002) and exhibit reduced immune functioning (cacioppo, hawkley, & berntson, 2003).

because belongingness is vital (baumeister & leary, 1995) and social exclusion thwarts the need to belong (williams, 2007), people are especially motivated to reconnect with others after being socially excluded (maner, dewall, baumeister, & schaller, 2007).

for example, social exclusion increases engagement in strategies, such as behavioral mimicry (lakin, chartrand, & arkin, 2008), which can increase feelings of closeness (ashton-james, van baaren, chartrand, decety, & karremans, 2007).

if people listen to increase their own feelings of social connection, then when their need to belong is threatened, they may be especially motivated to listen to their friends share emotional, but not necessarily descriptive, information.
thus, in this paper, we test this belongingness hypothesis - which is that the need to belong motivates people to listen to their friends disclose emotional, but not descriptive, information.
study 2 manipulates the need to belong, to examine whether increasing belonging needs increases how much people want to listen to emotional, but not descriptive, disclosure.
one item from each factor (items 6 and 12) had low factor loadings (−0.22 and −0.22), possibly because they measured expressing interest, rather than wanting to listen.
specifically, the greater the need to belong, the more people wanted to listen to their friends disclose emotional, but not descriptive, information.
it was only associated with a desire to listen to emotional disclosure.

because these data are correlational, it is unclear whether the need to belong motivates listening to emotional disclosure, or whether wanting to listen to emotional disclosure affects the need to belong.
social exclusion paradigms are commonly used to increase belonging needs.
negative moods might motivate listening to emotional disclosure as a means to engage in mood repair.
for instance, people may want to hear an uplifting story to feel better or a depressing story to remind them that things could be worse.

study 2 study 2 tested the hypothesis that increasing the need to belong, and not negative mood, increases how much people want to listen to their friends disclose emotional, but not descriptive, information.
based on prior research (pickett et al., 2004), we predicted that reliving social exclusion would increase belonging needs more than reliving academic failure or a neutral event.
we additionally predicted that increasing belonging needs would, in turn, be related to an increased desire to listen to emotional, but not descriptive, disclosure.

we used this particular contrast coding because the key prediction was that exclusion would promote the desire to listen to emotional, not descriptive, disclosure more than the failure and neutral conditions combined.

as in study 1, listening to descriptive disclosure was included as a covariate to ensure that the dependent variable reflected a desire to listen to emotional disclosure, and not a desire to listen in general.

because a significant total effect is not necessary for mediation to occur (hayes, 2009, 2013), we examined whether the exclusion manipulation indirectly increased the desire to listen emotional disclosure by increasing belonging needs.
thus, the exclusion manipulation increased the desire to listen to emotional disclosure, by increasing ntbs.

listening to descriptive disclosure was a significant covariate, b = 0.73, p b .001. next, we examined whether the exclusion manipulation indirectly increased the desire to listen descriptive disclosure by increasing belonging needs.
as expected, reliving social exclusion increased belonging needs more than reliving failure or a neutral event.
increased belonging needs were, in turn, related to an increase in the desire to listen to emotional, but not descriptive, disclosure.
thus, it is possible that ntbs operated as a mediator, whereas mood did not, because ntbs and listening were measured at the trait level, and mood was measured at the state level.
when people feel poorly about themselves, they may strive to form connections via listening in order to resolve these feelings.
thus, an alternative explanation is that general threats to self-esteem, rather than the need to belong, motivate people to listen.

lastly, we extend this work by examining whether the desire to listen translates into people's behavioral intentions to listen to a particular friend disclose emotional information, rather than merely assess the desire to listen to friends' emotional disclosures in general.

study 3 study 3 tested the hypothesis that increasing the need to belong, and not decreasing self-esteem per se, increases people's behavioral intentions to listen to a friend disclose emotional, but not descriptive, information.
to manipulate the need to belong, participants were either excluded or included by other participants in an on-line ball tossing game (williams, cheung, & choi, 2000).
we predicted that exclusion, more than inclusion, would increase the need to belong.
as ntbs increased, the desire to listen to descriptive disclosure decreased, b = −0.20, p = .03, indicating that ntbs was not associated with an increased desire to listen to emotional disclosure.

because the indirect effect of the exclusion manipulation on listening to emotional disclosure via mood was close to significant, we tested mood and belonging as simultaneous mediators to assure that belonging, and not mood, was driving the effects.
belongingness mediates the effect of the exclusion manipulation on the desire to listen to emotional disclosure (study 2).

j. hackenbracht, k. gasper / journal of experimental social psychology 49 (2013) 915-921 we predicted that increasing belonging needs, rather than a lack of self-esteem or negative mood, would increase behavioral intentions to listen to emotional, but not descriptive, disclosure.

intentions to listen to descriptive disclosure was a significant covariate, b = 0.86, p b .001. we then examined whether the exclusion manipulation indirectly increased intentions to listen descriptive disclosure by increasing belonging needs.

the exclusion manipulation increased belonging needs, b = 3.19, p b .001. however, belongingness and intentions to listen to descriptive disclosure were unrelated, b = −0.09, p = .27. additionally, the indirect effect was not significant (indirect effect = −0.30, 95% ci [−1.04, 0.19]), indicating that mediation did not occur.
belongingness mediates the effect of the exclusion manipulation on behavioral intentions to listen to emotional disclosure (study 3).
general discussion people often disclose their own emotional experiences with close others, such as friends (rimé, 2009), as a means to increase their own feelings of social connection.
we hypothesized that people may want to listen to their friends' emotional disclosures for this same reason.
in support of this hypothesis, in three studies increases in the need to belong were associated with a greater desire to listen to emotional, but not descriptive, disclosure.
thus, increasing the need to belong did not increase the desire to listen to anything per se.
but rather, it increased the desire to listen to emotional disclosure in particular.
lastly, these studies revealed that the need to belong, not the listener's concurrent mood or feelings of self-worth, operated as the critical mechanism.
first, people who are especially concerned with social connection might be particularly good at listening to emotional disclosure.
that is, if the desire to listen translates into being a better listener, then speakers may benefit more from disclosing to listeners high, versus low, in the need to belong.
second, listening to another person disclose emotional, but not descriptive, information may fulfill belonging needs.
unfortunately, our data do not test this hypothesis, for they only reveal that the need to belong promotes the desire to listen, not the effect of listening on belonging.
third, people high in the need to belong may listen, as opposed to disclose, emotional information because it involves less risk for future rejection and may reduce people's own self-awareness.
thus, future work may want to examine whether listening to emotional disclosure proves to be a low risk method to fulfill belongingness needs.

fourth, future work should examine whether the valence of the emotional information being disclosed, such as whether the speaker is disclosing a positive or negative emotional experience, differentially affects people's desire to listen.
lastly, we found that belonging needs promoted behavioral intentions to listen to emotional disclosure, but research is still needed to examine whether these results extend to actual behavior.
although in the same way that people disclose emotional information for many different reasons (see rimé, 2007, 2009), people likely listen to emotional disclosure for many reasons.

for example, people may be motivated to listen out of concern for other people's well-being (crocker, 2011), to obtain useful information, or to increase the likelihood that others will listen to them in the future.
this research extends prior work by focusing not on how speakers benefit from disclosure, but on how listeners may benefit from it.
the data indicate that people who listen with "all ears" may do so because it may help them satisfy their own need to belong.
getting a cue: the need to belong and enhanced sensitivity to social cues.
ostracism by a computer lowers belonging, control, self-esteem, and meaningful existence.

pdf_file: /content/drive/MyDrive/Datasets/Third_dataset/Not all social exclusions are created equal  Emotional distress following social exclusion is moderated by exclusion paradigm.pdf
causal_sentence: ostracism by a computer is sufficient to lower self-reported levels of belonging, control, self-esteem, and meaningful existence.
results indicated that ostracized participants performed more poorly and experienced lower positive mood and relatedness than included participants.

although no direct effects of ostracism on intrinsic motivation were found, in both studies ostracism indirectly affected intrinsic motivation through positive mood, such that ostracism led to poorer mood and, in turn, lower intrinsic motivation.
recent research has suggested that the act of being ignored or excluded ostracized by others is at best an unpleasant experience (williams, 1997, 2007).
not only do people dislike being ostracized, but the experience itself can be quite unsettling, emotionally painful, and cognitively debilitating (williams, 2007).
ostracism has repeatedly been shown to cause decrements in the self-esteem, mood, and feelings of meaningfulness, control, and belonging of targets of the act.

the effects of experiencing ostracism have even been found to be qualitatively different from (and worse than) experiencing other negative events, such as verbal dispute (zadro, williams, & richardson, 2005), underscoring the importance of studying this specific phenomenon.
moreover, research has also suggested that ostracism behaviors are indeed prevalent in organizations (einarsen, 2000; leymann, 1990; vartia, 1991).

being ignored during a water cooler conversation, excluded from a coworker's weekend barbecue, deliberately dropped from an integral e-mail chain, given the silent treatment by an irritated supervisor, or moved to an isolated office all constitute forms of ostracism that people may experience at work.

in addition, some research has suggested that threats to feelings of relatedness (e.g., being ostracized) can potentially interfere with people's ability to experience intrinsic motivation (i.e., the willingness to complete tasks for the sheer enjoyment they bring; e.g., deci & ryan, 2000).

thus, the present study sought to examine whether the experience of ostracism can influence individuals' performance on an interesting task and their intrinsic motivation for the task and to explore the roles that affect and feelings of relatedness might play in explaining these potential relationships.
initial research has even shown repeated and/or protracted acts of ostracism to be associated with severe depression and maladaptive behaviors (williams, 2007).
findings to date on this topic have demonstrated how pervasive and far-reaching the effects of experiencing ostracism can be.
he suggested that targets respond to acts of ostracism initially in a "reflexive" stage with feelings of shock and abrupt, emotional pain.

later, after this shock wears off, people enter a "reflective" stage during which they begin coping with the ostracism experience by cognitively appraising the events (i.e., making attributions as to why they were ostracized, etc.).
he argued that ostracism threatens individuals' fundamental needs for belonging, control over their environments, self-esteem, and a meaningful existence.
how people respond to an act of ostracism depends on the nuances of the act and which of these needs are threatened the most.

for instance, some research has shown that people seek out social interaction after being rejected (e.g., maner, dewall, baumeister, & schaller, 2007), whereas other research has found people to behave aggressively toward others (twenge, baumeister, tice, & stucke, 2001).
thus, the nature of the experience of ostracism can provide us clues as to how people will respond to the event.
in addition, researchers have concluded that, in many cases, ostracism yields unique effects on people that aren't borne out when they experience other negative (interpersonal) episodes.

the reason being, ignoring or excluding someone can prevent that person from being able to respond to the behavior or redress the situation at hand; it is a generally ineffective strategy to try to communicate with someone who won't listen or pay attention.

thus, unlike targets of dispute, harassment, or insults, whose retorts and acts of retaliation may more readily be perceived as effective, targets of ostracism are often left feeling powerless, especially after repeated or protracted episodes.

not only are acts of ostracism or exclusion ary isolating behaviors common in organizations (einarsen et al., 1994, as cited in einarsen, 2000; vartia, 1991; williams, 2001), but these behaviors may be perceived or experienced as distinct from other such bullying or emotionally abusive behaviors.
thus, evidence from a variety of perspectives suggests we should expect the experience of ostracism to be unique compared to the experience of other negative events and interpersonal behaviors.

ostracism and task performance in light of the evidence that suggests the effects of ostracism are unique, one particular question that remains is how being ostracized at work might affect people's ability to complete their work tasks.

in some cases, people can be un intentionally excluded from meetings where important inostracism and performance 285 formation is disseminated (i.e., left "out of the loop"; see jones et al., 2009) and therefore be unable to complete their work.

in other cases, because of how strongly people tend to react to ostracism (williams, 2007), we might expect the experience, to some extent, to interfere with people's ability to attend to others things (e.g., their work) as they are consumed by and then cope with the experience.

from a more macro perspective, a recent study by ferris and colleagues (2008), which set out to demonstrate evidence of validity for a workplace ostracism scale, found that self-reports of experiencing ostracism were, in fact, negatively related to supervisor ratings of job performance.
although this finding is intriguing, the cross-sectional nature and general level of analysis of the data certainly help establish only that ostracism may lead to lower levels of performance.
other research at the task level offers stronger support for the notion that ostracism can negatively impact performance on subsequent tasks.

furthermore, he suggested that after people are ostracized, their basic needs for belonging, self-esteem, control, and meaningfulness are threatened and that during the reflective stage, people behave in ways designed to recoup threatened needs.

along these lines, recent work by beal, weiss, barros, and macdermid (2005) suggested that experiencing an affective event at work (e.g., ostracism) can cause people to allocate cognitive resources away from the task at hand and to the experience itself.

some research does suggest that people may be so consumed by the experience of ostracism that they allocate resources to recovering, making attributions, or ruminating about the event, thus making it more difficult to attend to other tasks.

baumeister and colleagues (2002) found that participants who completed a questionnaire and were told they would end up alone later in life performed significantly more poorly on the analytic section of the gre than did those who were told they would live a normal, socially fulfilling life.
the poorer performance witnessed on these more demanding tasks is consistent with the notion that the experience of exclusion is debilitating and consumes cognitive resources.
ostracism and intrinsic motivation a second question we wanted to address was how being ostracized might affect people's ability to experience a subsequent task as intrinsically motivating.

research on motivation from self determination theory (deci & ryan, 2000) has suggested that various needs, including people's needs for relatedness,2 must be fulfilled in order to experience intrinsic motivation.

it follows that to the extent the experience of ostracism at work can lead to decrements in feelings of relatedness, then people's ability to experience their work as intrinsically motivating should be hampered as well.
for example, ryan and grolnick (1986) found lower levels of intrinsic motivation for academic activities in students who found their teachers to be cold and uncaring.
ilardi, leone, kasser, and ryan (1993) found perceptions of relatedness at work to be positively related to job satisfaction and personal well-being for employees.
whether or not experiencing lower levels of relatedness can influence individuals' intrinsic motivation on a subsequent task, however, remains an unanswered question.
however, some research has suggested that being in a positive mood can help foster the experience of intrinsic motivation.
a study by isen and reeve (2005) found that people in a positive mood found enjoyable tasks to be more intrinsically motivating than participants in a neutral mood.
the authors argue that being in a positive mood can enhance people's experiences of intrinsic motivation by heightening the level of enjoyment people experience.
to the extent that ostracism can worsen people's mood, it may, in turn, decrease people's ability to experience a task as intrinsically motivating.
by being in a poorer mood, people may not be able to experience this enhancement of enjoyment of engaging in a task that does occur when in a positive mood.
thus, experiencing a task that leads to decrements in feelings of relatedness may affect people's ability to experience intrinsic motivation by also influencing people's mood.

the present research the goal of the present research was to determine whether the experience of ostracism can cause decrements in people's performance and intrinsic motivation on a subsequent, interesting task.
based on previous research, we expected ostracism to have a negative influence on performance.
h1a: the experience of ostracism will lead to lower levels of performance on a subsequent task compared to the experience of inclusion.
as previously mentioned, williams's (2007) temporal model of ostracism suggests that as the shock of being ostracized wears off, people begin to cope and recover from the experience.

thus, we expected that ostracized participants initially would perform more poorly relative to participants who were not ostracized, but that over time, as participants recouped from the experience, any performance differences would either no longer persist or be substantially reduced.

h1b: the experience of ostracism will lead to declines in levels of performance relative to initial measures of performance compared to the experience of inclusion, but such performance differences will be smaller when performance is measured at a later point in time.
h2a: the experience of ostracism will lead to lower levels of positive mood compared to the experience of inclusion.
if the negative effects of ostracism do wear off over time, we should expect mood to improve over time as well.

h2b: the experience of ostracism will lead to lower levels of positive mood on initial measures compared to the experience of inclusion, but such differences in positive mood will be smaller at later measures of positive mood.

because being in a positive mood has been associated with better performance (beal et al., 2005; erez & isen, 2002), it may be that mood serves as an underlying mechanism for explaining ostracism's effects on performance.

h2c: the relationship between ostracism and performance will be mediated by positive mood such that ostracism will be negatively related to positive mood, and positive mood, in turn, will be positively related to performance.
in addition to testing the effects of ostracism on subsequent task performance, we also wanted to test whether ostracism can lead to decrements in intrinsic motivation on a subsequent task.

because we were interested in examining decrements in intrinsic motivation, the target activity that participants engaged in after being ostracized or included needed to be something that was moderately interesting in order to avoid witnessing any floor effects in the study.
self determination theory (deci & ryan, 2000) posits that people must have their needs for relatedness fulfilled in order to experience intrinsic motivation.
previous research has suggested that ostracism thwarts people's needs for relatedness belonging ness williams et al., 2000); thus, we expected to replicate that finding.

if ostracism serves to thwart people's needs for relatedness, and if relatedness is necessary for the experience of intrinsic motivation, we might expect ostracism to have a negative effect on intrinsic motivation.

in particular, we would expect this effect via relatedness: participants who are ostracized should report decrements in relatedness needs which should translate into lower levels of intrinsic motivation for the subsequent task they engage in.
h3a: the experience of ostracism will lead to lower levels of intrinsic motivation compared to the experience of inclusion.
h3b: the experience of ostracism will lead to lower levels of feelings of relatedness compared to the experience of inclusion.

lustenberger and jagacinski h3c: feelings of relatedness will mediate the relationship between ostracism and intrinsic motivation, such that ostracism will lead to lower levels of relatedness, compared to inclusion, and relatedness, in turn, will be positively related to intrinsic motivation.

because research has shown that being in a good mood can lead to increased intrinsic motivation for a task (isen & reeve, 2005) and to the extent that ostracism can worsen mood, ostracism may negatively influence intrinsic motivation.

h3d: positive mood will mediate the relationship between ostracism and intrinsic motivation, such that ostracism will be related to lower levels of positive mood, compared to inclusion, and positive mood, in turn, will be positively related to intrinsic motivation.

this activity was selected because it was found to be relatively interesting through pretesting, it could be used to measure performance, and participants could receive online feedback on their performance as they engaged in the task.
thus, in some condiostracism and performance 289 tions, the computerized players can be programmed to ostracize the participant, whereas in others they can be programmed to include the participant.

this particular manipulation can systematically induce ostracism (or inclusion) without relying on confederates or actors, and its effects on relatedness and mood have been shown to be relatively strong and comparable to face-to-face ostracism manipulations (williams et al., 2002).

because this was not the case with positive mood and because prior research on performance and intrinsic motivation has demonstrated relationships with positive mood, we decided to focus only on positive mood in the present research.
including the pretest control variables could help account for such individual differences, thereby increasing the power of the analyses conducted (see becker, 2005).

for h3b, as expected, a t test did reveal that ostracized participants experienced lower levels of relatedness than included participants t 69 4 05 p 001 g 0 96 although we did not observe any direct effects of ostracism on intrinsic motivation, it was still possible that an indirect effect of ostracism on intrinsic motivation could exist through relatedness or positive mood.

shrout and bolger (2002) argued that the traditional requirement that an independent variable be related to the dependent variable in testing for mediation can be relaxed when effect sizes may be small, which maybe the case here thus we aimed to test whether relatedness could explain a possible indirect effect between ostracism and intrinsic motivation (h3c).

preacher and hayes (2004, 2008) recommend bootstrapping, particularly with smaller sample sizes, to reduce bias in assessing the significance of the so bel test statistic a distribution of products which includes the so bel test statistic ab tends to be positively skewed and using a normal distribution to assess the significance of the statistic can result in an underpowered test.

by the time participants reached any of the intrinsic motivation measures, they had already completed a number of tasks and responded to several questionnaires activities that could have served to help participants recoup from the ostracism experience-and showed recovery in positive mood.
we also controlled for pretest interest in the analyses because, in both conditions, it was significantly related to self-reported intrinsic motivation.
first, across two studies, we found that when we controlled for participants ' initial performance on a word-search task, ostracism had a negative influence on performance.
thus, it appeared as though the experience of ostracism interfered with participants ' capability to perform on a cognitive task.
performance among ostracized participants did not appear to improve across time, either-unlike mood, which did appear to improve over time.
however, the initial decrements in mood that accompanied the experience of ostracism were not found to mediate the performance effect observed.

the drops in performance we did observe among ostracized participants could be stronger with less interesting tasks; a more interesting task might serve as a more appealing means to recover from the ostracism experience than a boring task would.

along these lines, research using a different social rejection manipulation found a stronger decline in task performance among rejected participants for a relatively less interesting task (baumeister et al., 2005).

the findings from the two present studies extend this research by demonstrating for the first time that ostracism can negatively influence performance, though to a lesser extent, even on interesting tasks.
it could be that for relatedness to influence intrinsic motivation, the target activity itself would have to be social in nature and be the source of the ostracism.
this could explain why the decrements in relatedness caused by experiencing ostracism did not translate into rating a distinct activity as less enjoyable.
future research should explore whether a task needs to be social in nature for feelings of relatedness to play a role in determining people's intrinsic motivation for a given activity.
another reason why we may have observed no significant relationships between relatedness and intrinsic motivation could have to do with the nature of the cyberball activity.
one could argue that it was not such an activity that could allow participants to personally connect with other people and help promote fulfillment of their relatedness needs.

future research should examine whether facilitating, 300 lustenberger and jagacinski rather than thwarting, the fulfillment of relatedness needs can lead to increases in intrinsic motivation for a task.

although feelings of relatedness did not appear to play a role in predicting intrinsic motivation, in both studies we did find that ostracism was indirectly related to self-reported intrinsic motivation through positive mood while controlling for initial interest.
ostracism led to lower levels of positive mood, which itself was associated with greater feelings of intrinsic motivation.

positive mood can arguably be viewed as a more general measure of people's feelings than a measure of fulfillment of relatedness needs, and though the measures were moderately correlated in both studies, positive mood may have served as a better transmitter of the effects of ostracism on intrinsic motivation.
encountering an event that lowers one's level of positive mood could have the effect of reducing one's ability to experience a subsequent task as interesting and enjoyable.

this may explain why in both studies we witnessed a significant indirect effect of ostracism on intrinsic motivation, controlling for pretest interest, through positive mood, but not through relatedness.
this raises the possibility that any experience that reduces feelings of positive mood could ultimately inhibit the experience of intrinsic motivation on a subsequent task.
when participants engaged in the performance trials first, those who were ostracized did not perform as well.

this decline in performance may have allowed a poorer mood to persist longer than for ostracized participants who engaged in the free-choice trial first instead and who, perhaps, could more freely recover from the ostracism experience.
although this study has demonstrated what can happen when people are ostracized, it is unclear whether we can expect similar effects among employees working in organizations.
however, it is quite possible that effects would be stronger and more persistent in the field where individuals who are ostracized may experience exclusion on a daily basis.
williams (2007) argued that repeated or drawn-out acts of ostracism can have profound effects on mental health and functioning.
in sum, the results suggest that ostracism can have important effects on performance, feelings of relatedness, positive mood, and indirectly on intrinsic motivation.

the relationship between ostracism and performance can even be considered in light of individuals intentionally, passively aggressively ostracizing others with the intent to impede their progress on work tasks (e.g., failing to pass along vital information).
it could very well be that certain types of people are likely to ostracize more than others, and, likewise, certain types of people may be more prone to being ostracizes than others.

pain res manage 2008 13 4 309 319 objective: to examine the hypothesis that experimental threats to social belongingness, interacting with individual differences in attachment security, cause modification of pain threshold reports by individuals who report high pain thresholds at baseline.
results: those with high anxious attachment and high baseline pain thresholds reported higher post manipulation pain thresholds in the exclusion conditions than in the control conditions.
those with low anxious attachment and high baseline pain thresholds reported lower post manipulation pain thresholds in the exclusion conditions than in the control conditions.
conclusions: across studies, results suggested that post manipulation pain threshold reports of individuals with high baseline pain thresholds were particularly responsive to social exclusion.
the form of the response was dependent on the level of anxious attachment.
the present studies provide evidence that variance in pain threshold reports not accounted for by pain intensity may reflect the use of pain reports to satisfy social needs.
this work also suggests that baseline measures of pain thresholds may, in interaction with psychological variables, have predictive power beyond serving as a control variable.
pain tolerance is measured by asking participants to stop a painful stimulus when the pain is no longer bearable.

chapman et al (1), in a review of pain assessment techniques, argued that pain threshold measures produce relatively inconsistent results and are subject to influence from placebo effects, expectancy, instructional set and other psychological factors.
therefore, one basis for examining the meaning of pain threshold reports may be tracking discrepancies between pain tolerance (as a marker of pain intensity) and pain threshold.
conditions that influence pain tolerance and pain threshold differently (8-14) may provide insight into factors other than pain intensity that drive pain threshold reports.
one potentially important factor in examining the meaning of pain threshold reports is that such reports may be uniquely vulnerable to subjective distortion.
pain tolerance measures should be less subject to distortion than self-reports of pain threshold because of the extent to which they rely on nonverbal expression of pain (15).
thus, shifts in pain threshold not accompanied by similar shifts in pain tolerance (or vice-versa) may indicate an influence on pain sensitivity reports other than pain intensity.
similarly, the variance remaining in pain threshold reports after controlling for pain tolerance scores may reflect, at least in part, subjective distortion in reports of pain sensitivity.
in this interpersonal context, pain reports may take on a social communication function.
some participants may believe that a pain task allows them to communicate interpersonal qualities such as stoicism, toughness or vulnerability (2).

taken together, this analysis suggests that those who report high pain thresholds (especially while controlling for pain tolerance) may be individuals who subjectively distort pain reports because they believe such reports convey important social meaning.
as a result, postbaseline pain threshold reports may be distorted to satisfy salient social concerns, such as belongingness needs.

previous research examining the predictive power of baseline pain thresholds in the context of reminders of mortality supports the notion that those who report high pain thresholds at baseline use subsequent pain threshold reports to satisfy psychological needs.
reminders of mortality have been shown to motivate individuals to strive for self-esteem and validation of their personal worldviews as compensation for anxiety about death (18).

one interpretation of these data is that individuals who attached personal meaning to pain reports at baseline (ie, those with high baseline pain thresholds) and who had been reminded of death were particularly motivated to appear to be without pain in the post manipulation pain task.

demonstration of imperviousness to pain may have provided relief from death anxiety by providing a sense of invulnerability to physical threats (potentially a means for feeling less vulnerable to death in the short term and/or an important aspect of the worldview of those who value low pain sensitivity).

importantly, no effects across experimental conditions were evident for post manipulation pain tolerance, suggesting that the manipulation influenced subjective reports rather than degree of pain intensity.
overall, these data suggested that pain thresholds were manipulated to satisfy psychological needs arising from reminders of mortality.
the present research more specifically examines the hypothesis that pain threshold reports can be used to satisfy the psychological need for belongingness.

if pain threshold reports are seen by those with high baseline pain thresholds as serving a social communication function, then conditions that heighten belongingness needs should lead to predictable changes in subsequent pain threshold reports.
one experience that has been shown to increase the need felt for belongingness is social exclusion.

individuals randomly assigned to experience or recall social exclusion have been shown to demonstrate increased motivation for interpersonal connection (19) and heightened attention to social information (20).

how an individual responds to the desire for connection, when spurred by exclusion, is influenced by the individual's level of interpersonal security in a fashion that is particularly relevant in the context of pain research.
expressions of emotional distress, including reports of pain, provide a signal of vulnerability that can motivate caregiving responses by others (21).
although useful for recruiting social support, such expressions of vulnerability also entail a degree of social risk.
expressions of emotional distress can be met by negative forms of support, such as interpersonal rejection, that exacerbate rather than reduce the distress (21).
as a result, individuals withhold signals of vulnerability unless they are reasonably confident their distress will be met with support (22).
the perceived consequences of turning to others for social support, therefore, may influence the expression of pain.

those high on the dimension of anxious attachment tend to be concerned about the possibility of further social harm resulting from calls for support because they tend to doubt their acceptability to others.
as a result, anxiously attached individuals are hypervigilant for signs of rejection.
although these individuals strongly desire support and validation from others, they also fear that pursuing support will lead to rejection.
those high on the dimension of avoidant attachment doubt the availability of support because they view others as unreliable.
avoidantly attached individuals tend to be uncomfortable turning to others for support because they do not expect such calls for support to be helpful in relieving distress.

those who are less secure in the availability of quality support respond in a more defensive fashion, withholding expressions of vulnerability to reduce the risk of further social harm or disappointing support provision.
first, those who report higher pain thresholds at baseline (ie, before exclusion) should be more likely to view subsequent pain reports as having a socially expressive function.

thus, when belongingness needs are heightened by social exclusion, those with high baseline pain thresholds should seek to resolve their social needs through subsequent pain threshold performance, more so than those with low baseline pain thresholds.
second, the performance of those with high baseline pain thresholds should depend on their level of attachment security.
those with low levels of security should be hesitant to reveal vulnerability and should thus report relatively high post manipulation pain thresholds.
such a display of invulnerability should help ease concerns about rejection for insecure individuals.
those with high levels of security should be comfortable with vulnerability following exclusion and, thus, should report relatively low pain thresholds.
low pain threshold reports may be used by secure individuals as a means of recruiting care and concern.
after 4 min, if a participant had not yet removed her or his arm from the cold water, the cold pressor task was ended (participants were not informed of the time limit before the task).
further ratings were not included because participant attrition limited the data points available.
pain tolerance: when participants removed their arm from the cold water, the number of seconds elapsed after immersion in the water was recorded as pain tolerance.

the asq focuses on relationships in general rather than romantic relationships, which makes it more appropriate for adolescent and young adult populations, who may have less experience with serious, romantic relationships (27).
because there were no consistent two-variable interaction effects across studies, interactions at the twovariable level will not be reported in any study for the sake of brevity.
a main effect of anxious attachment was also found, such that higher anxious attachment was related to a more negative mood, β=-0.330, p=0.009, r2=0.083.

discussion the results of study 1 suggested that individuals who reported higher pain thresholds in the baseline pain task were more likely to adjust their subsequent pain threshold reports across experimental conditions than those who reported low baseline pain thresholds.

these results were found while controlling for both baseline and post manipulation pain tolerance, suggesting that the effects are more attributable to displays of pain than variation in experienced pain intensity.
these data are consistent with the hypothesis that those with high baseline pain thresholds use pain threshold reports to regulate social needs.

the reaction of those with high baseline pain thresholds to social exclusion appeared to depend on levels of anxious, but not avoidant, attachment (see general discussion for consideration of this point).
those with high baseline pain thresholds and low anxious attachment reported significantly lower post manipulation pain thresholds in the exclusion condition than in the inclusion condition.
these participants appeared to respond to exclusion with a display of vulnerability to pain.

conversely, although the trend did not reach significance, those with high baseline pain thresholds and high anxious attachment reported somewhat higher post manipulation pain thresholds in the exclusion condition than in the inclusion condition.
this is consistent with a show of invulnerability to pain, although the weakness of the effect renders its reliability questionable.

the exclusion manipulation did not influence participants' reports of discomfort or pain tolerance, suggesting the relatively manipulable nature of pain threshold reports are especially targeted as a means of regulating social needs.
furthermore, baseline pain threshold was unrelated to mood, either alone or in interaction with other variables, suggesting that mood cannot account for these effects.
study 1, then, provides some support for the argument that pain threshold reports can be used to satisfy social concerns.
although statistical support was weak in the case of those with high anxious attachment, this may be a function of the nature of the control condition.

anxiously attached individuals, who are hypervigilant for cues of rejection, may have subjectively experienced noninclusion even when receiving their fair share of throws (ie, 10 or one-quarter of the throws).

that is, watching 30 of 40 throws go to other participants may have led to some feelings of exclusion (note that the manipulation check asked about the degree of inclusion by other players rather than subjective feelings of inclusion).
it is possible, then, that anxiously attached individuals in the present study experienced heightened belongingness needs in both the inclusion and exclusion conditions.
incorporating a different manipulation allowed not only increased precision, but the opportunity to examine general iz ability across different op e rationalizations of social exclusion.

as with the trend in study 1, those with high baseline pain thresholds and high anxious attachment reported particularly high post manipulation pain thresholds in the exclusion condition, relative to the control condition.

that this effect is significant when using a more asocial control condition in study 2 suggests that the small effect in study 1 may be a result of the control condition raising belongingness concerns for anxiously attached individuals.

thus, this result may best be framed as suggesting that those with high baseline pain thresholds and high anxious attachment may not, under normal conditions, be motivated to maintain the appearance of pain insensitivity across trials.
it may also be possible that these individuals, as they become more comfortable with the experimental setting, become increasingly motivated to report low pain thresholds to recruit sympathy.
