thus, we cannot rule out differences in attributions as causing differences in the basic need satisfaction outcomes.
our failure to fi nd attributions leading to different basic need satisfaction outcomes may stem more from study limitations than from fl aws.

for example, those ostracized while possessing a temporary group membership may recover faster than those ostracized while possessing a permanent group membership because a temporary group membership is less central to one's identity than a permanent group membership and therefore easier to escape from.

those in the green or blue group membership conditions had no previous experience of discrimination based on the color of their cyberball player compared to those in the gender group membership condition where individuals may have experienced quite a bit of real-life sexism.

participants may have developed coping mechanisms based on past experiences of being discriminated against due to a permanent group membership that they would not necessarily possess when being discriminated against for the fi rst time based on a group membership (see crandall et al., 2000).
individuals might feel a sense of group membership in a work group, but this group will likely only last a short time.
our choice of group membership does not rule out the possibility of alternative results occurring with different group memberships.

future research might make it blatantly clear why participants are being ostracized compared to having an ambiguous situation, especially considering research fi nds different associations between attributions to discrimination and self-esteem based on the ambiguity of the situation (see major & o'brien, 2005).

according to the discounting hypothesis (kelly, 1973) we would expect when given an explanation for the negative event, a group membership, participants should recover faster from an ostracism experience due to being able to blame the negative outcome on being a member of a particular group.
found that immediately after being ostracized, individuals do not discount the ostracism due to being ostracized by members of an outgroup.

future research might further investigate the discounting hypothesis and its role in the refl ective stage of recovery from being ostracized to determine when discounting might protect an ostracized individual.
conclusion attributing negative outcomes to a groupbased membership has been argued to have self-protective properties because this type of attribution defl ects self-threat (crocker & major, 1989).

however, it has also been argued that, to the degree the group membership is central to one's identity, the attributions to the group membership are not helpful because the self is still centrally implicated (branscombe et al., 1999; major et al., 2003; schmitt & branscombe, 2002a).

we found that when par-ticipants were ostracized while possessing a temporary group membership, one that was not central to their identity, recovery from a needs threat was signifi cantly better than when participants were ostracized while possessing a permanent group membership.
the more an identity is an aspect of the self, the more threatening making attributions for negative outcomes is.
regardless of group membership, ostracized participants were more likely to make both internal and external attributions for the outcomes than included participants.
this suggests that when negative events occur, individuals search for explanations both externally and internally of the self.
ultimately, group membership may only act as a buffer against ostracism when it is not a central aspect of one's identity, and therefore escapable.
results suggest greater group 125 wirth & williams ostracized while possessing a group membership identifi cation does not buffer ostracism's negative effect.
perceiving discrimination against one's gender group has different implications for well-being in women and men.
ostracism by a computer lowers belonging, control, self-esteem, and meaningful existence.
as it stands, only a few previous studies have found evidence that immediate reactions to ostracism are moderated by individual differences.
results indicated that when personality effects were observed in the control condition, they tended to be attenuated in the exclusion condition.
more broadly, however, the findings provide little evidence that negative reactions to ostracism are strongly influenced by individual differences in personality.

accordingly, there is robust support for the idea that individuals are highly sensitive to cues indicating the possibility of social exclusion and that being ostracized is psychologically distressing (gerber & wheeler, 2009).
importantly, two recent studies found that certain personality attributes are associated with responses to ostracism (onoda et al., 2010; wirth, lynam, & williams, 2010).

these physiological effects complement self-report findings indicating that ostracism is associated with decreased mood and reduced satisfaction of important psychological needs (gerber & wheeler, 2009).

thus far, there is little evidence indicating that the immediate experience of distress associated with ostracism is moderated by individual differences, including gender, introversion extraversion collectivism individualism loneliness, need for belonging, and social anxiety (see williams, 2007, for a review).

these largely null findings for personality are consistent with the notion that the experience of ostracism reflects a strong situation, that is, an event that produces similar affective and behavioral responses across individuals regardless of their personalities (e.g.
the authors argue that these individuals ''may find social interaction so aversive that being removed from such an interaction may provide relief'' (p. 397).
these authors also found that a facet of agreeableness from the five factor model (labeled straight forwardness exacerbated reactions to ostracism.
found that individuals with low self-esteem, who tend to be more attuned to social rejection, reported more social pain following ostracism than those with high self-esteem.
in light of these intriguing findings, there is a pressing need to continue to evaluate whether personality attributes moderate reactions to social exclusion.

in doing so, we investigated the following questions: (1) does ostracism lead to reduced need satisfaction, (2) does personality moderate reactions to ostracism by buffering or exacerbating negative reactions, or (3) does ostracism act as a strong situation and diminish the effects of personality on need satisfaction?

in addition to attempting to replicate previous findings of personality moderation, we predicted that personality traits associated with affiliation, such as agreeableness, would be more strongly related to distress following ostracism given that these individuals are closely attuned to social bonds.
those with psychopathic features) may be less invested in social connection and therefore somewhat immune from the effects of ostracism.
neuroticism, low self-esteem) should exhibit greater distress following ostracism given that they tend to be more sensitive to social rejection.
in contrast, personality traits associated with positive affect, such as extraversion, might buffer reactions to ostracism.
psychopathy is typically described as a combination of impulsive and antisocial tendencies accompanied by low levels of anxiety and fear.
narcissism is associated with arrogance, entitlement, and a willingness to exploit others; it was assessed using the narcissistic personality inventory (raskin & terry, 1988).
thus, we failed to replicate the finding that self-esteem buffers negative reactions to ostracism (onoda et al., 2010).
openness was associated with higher levels of need satisfaction in both the control condition (r = .49, p < .001) and the exclusion condition (r = .28, p < .001).

in contrast, traits associated with an obsessive compulsive personality disorder predicted less need satisfaction in both the control condition (r = .21, p = .048) and the exclusion condition (r = .19, p = .009).
low conscientiousness and agreeableness, antisocial personality) indicating that these features attenuated the negative effects of ostracism.
despite our increased sample size, we did not find widespread support for the idea that personality attributes are related to individual's reactions to ostracism.
rather, the five significant interactions indicated that effects of personality evident in the control condition were attenuated in the exclusion condition.

individuals high on openness tended to report higher levels of need satisfaction in both the control condition and the exclusion condition, whereas individuals with traits associated with obsessive compulsive personality disorder reported less need satisfaction in both conditions.
openness is related to a philosophical life approach and thus individuals high in this attribute might report more meaningful existence regardless of condition.

individuals with trait profiles that approximate obsessive compulsive traits are high in anxiety and conscientiousness which may make them susceptible to negative affect and more likely to report reduced need satisfaction.

we did not replicate the finding that low self-esteem exacerbates the effects of ostracism (onoda et al., 2010) nor did we replicate the finding that cluster a personality prototypically attenuates the effects of ostracism (wirth et al., 2010).
individuals low in this dimension tend to exhibit less concern for others and may therefore react less negatively to being ostracized.
future research may benefit from examining the moderating effects of specific facets of agreeableness in line with the arguments made by wirth et al.
as a result, comparisons between the sets of findings should be interpreted with some caution as differences in measures may explain the discrepancies in results.
furthermore, conventional wisdom is to assume that four item scales have less measurement error than single-item ratings.

regardless, caution is warranted when interpreting any single study and additional research is necessary to conclusively resolve which domains of personality consistently moderate the impact of ostracism.

we also note that other methods of inducing social rejection may differ in terms of situational strength and thus researchers should continue to search for personality moderators of reactions to ostracism using different methods and large sample sizes.
in general, however, our work suggests that immediate reactions to ostracism, as induced by the cyberball paradigm, may represent a strong situation.

this basic result is consistent with the idea that social exclusion triggers an immediate psychological alarm system that increases the likelihood that individuals will strive to maintain or repair their relationships with group members.
such an alarm system might be triggered regardless of the personality attributes of particular individuals.
